Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, in light of the report Taxation reform and the arts prepared for the Australia Council by KPMG and publicly released today, will the minister assure the House that a GST will not apply to entertainment such as families going to the movies or their kids going to rock concerts? Will the minister rule out asking an average Australian family to pay Peter Costello $4 every time of the honourthey go to the movies?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Again, I put to the opposition that I think you have to look very carefully at the way you are framing these questions. They are technically contrary to our standing orders, I am afraid. I ask the minister representing the minister for communications and the arts to respond, but technically most of these questions are out of order. I call the minister.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the provisions of standing order 147 which says: The Speaker may direct that the language of a question be changed if it seems to the Speaker unbecoming or not in conformity with the standing orders of the House. If, Mr Speaker, you are not of a mind to rule the question out of order, I would ask at least that you request that, pursuant to standing order 147, the opposition rephrase the question so that it comes within the standing orders of the House.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I think we are all aware that questions of this sort have been asked by both sides of the House over time. For that reason I am allowing the question. I have drawn attention to the fact that, technically, there are many questions from both sides that are not in accordance with standing orders. The honourable the minister, I am sure, would like to respond to this question.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Such an attractive invitation, Mr Speaker. Firstly, I will say this: the government will study the KPMG report and make its deliberations known in due course. We thank KPMG for the work and effort they have put into that report which is vital for the future development of arts policy. On the issue that the member for Canberra was nearly ruled out of order on, the same answer applies as I have already responded to in the House today. When the government finalises its package, it will be possessed of fairness and equity for Australians in dealing with the need to address taxation reformsomething that you had the opportunity to do and failed to do in 13 years. Taxation: Land Transport

Speaker: Mr MAREK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Can the minister advise the House how the failure to address taxation reform in the land transport sector by the previous government has unfairly hurt regional Australia, particularly in large electorates like Capricornia?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for his question. As the honourable member would be well aware, the costs of land transport, particularly road port, have a major impact on the cost of living in regional Australia, which our government is vitally interested in. Part of that impost is the current taxation system that the Australian Labor Party wants to protect.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: If you look at your history books, you will find that Labor created the taxation system we have at the moment with the wholesale sales tax and with the fuel excise. In 1993 the Labor Party went to the people of Australia and they promised that there would be no increases in taxes and they also promised tax cuts. Do you remember the l-a-w and the promise that there would be no increases in taxes, which turned into a l-i-e, a lie, in 1993 when you took the wholesale sales taxes from 15 per cent to 22 per cent? Mr Crean-Never ever!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Hotham will remain silent. Mr Tanner-Tell us about lies like your road funding promises.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Melbourne!

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: That impacts on every single thing that goes on in regional Australia which includes the commodities that are carried in there to be consumed by people in regional Australia. Every single thing that is manufactured in regional Australia is also transported out by road or by rail and that is impacted upon by the wholesale sales tax system that the Labor Party wants to protect. They increased the wholesale sales taxes in 1993 and they do not want to change it. This is the ridiculous system that they want to maintain. In 1993, they increased the sales tax on trucks for the road transport industry from 15 per cent to 22 per cent. If you go and buy spare parts such as new seat belts for that truck they are exempt because it is a safety item. But if you go and buy brake parts, airbags or lights, they are taxed at 22 per cent. How ridiculous is that system that the new truck is taxed at 22 per cent, and parts that are critical to the safety of that operation are also taxed at 22 per cent. That is the system that the Australian Labor Party wants transto protect. The created it. The Australian Labor Party created this system. In 1993, the Australian Labor Party said they would not increase taxes. That promise turned into an l-i-e, a lie, as the member for Charlton was allowed to get away with a while ago. It is the Australian Labor Party that now want to protect this system. They do not want to change it; they want to continue seeing the burdens of an unfair tax system loaded onto regional Australia in the same way as they want to see the unfair burdens of a lack of competition on the Australian waterfront loaded onto regional Australians. Mr Crean-Are you going to drop the fuel excise?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Botham interjects about fuel excise, Mr Speaker. Mr Crean-Are you going to drop it?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Botham will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: From 1983 until 1996, the Labor Party saw fuel excise go from 7c a litre to 36c a litre. That is your government. The Leader of the Opposition was the Minister for Finance through those years and they took the fuel excise straight up. That is a direct impost on regional Australia. You sit here with confected indignation and talk about what you want to do for regional Australia. There is not one person on the opposition benches that is serious about representing regional Australia. Our government wants to see a fairer taxation system for all regional Australians. Taxation: Medicare

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Do you recall your 'never ever' GST discussion on the Clive Robertson program on 19 April 1996 when you said, 'Clive, I have to repeat, I mean, everybody asks me about the GST and I said I'm not going to do it. Now, it's like Medicare.'? Does this mean your 'never ever' promise on Medicare is as genuine as your 'never ever' promise on GST?

Speaker: Mr BOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Our position is that we will go to the next election with a proposal to reform the Australian taxation system. Opposition members-Never ever! Never ever!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Members of the opposition will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Unlike the Labor Party that is wedded to an outdated, outmoded indirect taxation system, unlike the Australian Labor Party that is wedded to a personal income taxation system that in this current year will mean that a taxpayer on average weekly earnings will move from a 34 per cent rate at the margin to 43 per cent at the margin. That is the system that the Leader of the Opposition proposes that Australia maintain. Mr Crean-Never ever! You don't care about the never ever!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Botham will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He is also going to maintain an indirect taxation system that produced the increases on household items that I have referred to in earlier questions. Mr Speaker, I say to all honourable members in the House that question time over the last two days has not surprisingly been focused on the issue of taxation. Any person who takes a realistic, objective view of the Australian taxation system will know that, if we really care about the national interest, we cannot go on forever with the present taxation system. If we really care about the competitiveness of Australian industry in a hostile world economic environment, we can no longer tolerate a taxation system that penalises our manufactured exports and that says to the rest of the world, 'We're going to try to fight you for the markets of the world with one hand tied behind our backs.' Mr Crean-This is good.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: You think that is good, do you? Mr Crean-I said this is good, you fraud.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Hotham has already been warned. I suggest he remain silent.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He thinks it is good, apparently, that the Australian manufacturers be forced to compete with the rest of the world with one hand tied behind their backs. Mr Speaker, the coalition is committed to comprehensive taxation reform. Whenever the Leader of the Opposition opens his mouth on taxation, he has got form. They remember the dishonoured 1993 promises, they remember the budget deficit, they remember the fact that fuel excise rose-as my colleague the Minister for Transport and Regional Development said-from 7c a litre to 36c a litre. I have no doubt who they will believe when judgment comes. Commonwealth State Disability Agreement

Speaker: Mr BILSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Has the minister heard reports that negotiations on a Commonwealth State Disability Agreement have stalled? Can the minister update the House on the actual situation?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Many members will be aware that the development of the five-year Commonwealth State Disability Agreement has been under consideration and discussion between the Commonwealth and the states for some considerable time, and I know that the member for Dunkley has taken a particularly keen interest in this agreement, representing the interests of the constituents in his seat and in Victoria. I am pleased to say that yesterday I secured the signature of the last of the states. All states have now signed a new five-year agreement, also the Northern Territory. The ACT have indicated twice in writing to me that they will be doing so, given, of course, that the ACT had an election in the interim period. The outcome is significant, as all members would know, in setting in place a five-year agreement in conjunction with the states which gives certainty to those with disabilities about the level of funding. It has been a fundamental priority of this government and it has certainly been a personal priority for myself as the minister. The funds that will flow over that period of the agreement, the four years for accommodation support, amount to about $1.46 billion. In addition, the Commonwealth, which is responsible for employment and related services, will spend $1.07 billion over that four-year period. That constitutes approximately a five per cent increase on the original agreement amount and is made up of 3.38 per cent growth and an estimated 1.5 per cent indexation, and a supplementation for superannuation costs. We have been, during the course of the negotiations, subject to a range of misinformation, and I am glad to say that has not been echoed broadly in the disability sector. They have been extremely constructive, and I know that many of the representative bodies will be delighted to know that all states have now signed this agreement. Effectively, it means that, if the states meet the same level of increase that is provided for by the Commonwealth, for the first time ever in this country we will have a very marked uptrend in the amount of money that is relayed to the benefit of those people with disabilities. In addition, the announcement in the staying at home package of $15 million for those people who are looking after elderly disabled people will be an additional benefit which will flow through these agreements. It is a very significant agreement and it is a very significant achievement for this government, and I congratulate the Prime Minister. Public Hospital Funding

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it correct that your government's legislation placed a cut-off date of next Tuesday for negotiations with the states over public hospital funding? Is it also correct that, while your health minister is not even in the country between now and that cut-off date, your government is about to introduce a bill to allow you to abandon long term Medicare agreements with the states and to pay them for one year only? Why is your government deliberately sabotaging the Medicare agreements? Finally, without the Medicare agreements, what is to stop you or the states introducing co-payments for services in public hospitals if you are re-elected?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The assumption underlying the honourable member's question, as usual, is wrong. What the government is doing is to introduce legislation to give effect to the undertaking that I gave after the Premiers rather petulantly walked out of the last Premiers Conference, that is, the offer made by the Commonwealth would be honoured in full. I say again to the people of Australia: we will deliver every last dollar that we promised that we would deliver at the Premiers Conference. The allegations you make about co-payments are wrong. Our policy of opposition to a co-payment stands. It will not be altered. The only party in this place that wanted to introduce a co-payment was the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party wanted to introduce a co-payment and the Australian Labor Party's credentials on that issue ought to come under a lot more scrutiny than the credentials of the coalition. We will honour the promises that we put on the table at the last Premiers Conference. They represent a 15 per cent increase in real terms-I5 per cent over the next five years. And what the honourable member is saying is wrong. It is wrong in relation to undermining Medicare. It is wrong in relation to the co-payment and it is wrong to the extent that it implies that we will not honour in full the undertakings that I gave at the Premiers Conference.

Speaker: Mr FORREST
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I ask the minister to inform the House what outcomes were achieved at the recent World Trade Organisation ministerial meeting in Geneva. How will Australia benefit from those outcomes? What are the likely next steps in international trade negotiations?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Last Wednesday in Geneva at the second ministerial meeting of the Wodd Trade Organisation agreement was reached on a declaration which represents a quantum leap forward both in respect of the agricultural sector and the services the hard-pressed pork and citrus producers, who are now exporting a good proportion of their efforts, it is not going to be an instant magic wand but it is a step in the right tion. Mr O'Keefe--What are you talking about?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Burke will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: We reaffirmed the built-in agenda which was part of the Uruguay Round negotiations and which I would have thought members of the front bench would acknowledgeMr O'Keefe--The pork industry, and what else?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Burke will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: We export pork to Russia, in case you did not know. Mr O'Keefe--What, half a kilo?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: We have done so last year and this year and those exports are off a small base but expanding. I am proud of the pork industry's efforts to start exporting. You may not be, but I am. Mr O'Keefe--Just be honest with the pork industry.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Burke will remain silent. Mr O'Keefe-Just be honest with the pork industry.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I warn the honourable member for Burke. Trade Mr O'Keefe--You are telling porkies.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Burke will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It goes on. Against all odds, the citrus industry is now exporting 50 per cent of its production by dollar value. Mr O'Keefe-You are telling porkies.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Burke will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am proud of that and so is the coalition government-proud of those having a go at exporting. It is more than you encouraged in either the pork or the sector. For citrus industry. I want to say, Mr Speaker, that we did something else. In addition to affirming the built-in agenda, we provided for the preparadirec- tory work to commence-something which had been resisted-in September 1998, this year, and ahead of what had previously been contemplated. Again, that is a step in the right direction. I want to add, Mr Speaker, that what we did was in contrast to the white flag brigade from the Labor Party when it was in government with regard to trade negotiationsbilateral, regional and multilateral. Indeed, I remind the House that Senator Button said this about Labor's trade efforts: 'Everyone is down there in Foreign Affairs and Trade doing the multilaterals; no-one is doing anything about the bilaterals.' In Geneva, I also took the opportunity to pursue country to country negotiations, bilateral negotiations, with, once again, more enhancement for Australian exporters. I want to make one other point in response to the legitimate question of the member for Mallee. Australia at this time is a fiscal economic oasis in this part of the world. We have a budget surplus; you provided a $10billion budget deficit. We have a budget surplus that is helping our exporters. We have a budget surplus which is helping to confer safety, security and stability, as the Prime Minister has pointed out. We are a fiscal economic oasis, but we must safeguard our trading position. It is true that there is no such thing as an international level playing field, and it is also true that, arising out of some of the more recent developments in Asia, there are efforts by nations to cheat with regard to their trade circumstance, legally or otherwise. I highlight and I will continue to highlight that. I want to make the point, very bluntly, Mr Speaker, that the playing field is likely to become more lopsided, but we will do all we can to sensibly safeguard the situation of our exporters. So I say again that the government is proud to have created a budget surplus which makes this economy a fiscal economic oasis. We have turned around your $lOY2 billion deficit. You would have been a disaster for our exporters. One Nation Party

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Which are increasing at a much more rapid rate than

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition will address his question. If he has not a question, I will call the next questioner.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Given the importance of trade to increasing jobs and the impact on job growth, especially in Queensland with the collapse in Asian tourism, will you follow the lead of your Queensland ministerial colleague John Moore, and the Treasurer, and 17 other federal coalition members, by recommending to your party that any One Nation candidate in your electorate goes last on your how to vote card?

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I will not accept any lectures from the Leader of the Opposition on this particular matter. The parliament, its members and the nation as a whole will soon enough learn the exactitude of my response on that matter at the appropriate time when our candidates are confirmed in the field. Mr O'Connor-Show some leadership. Mr Bevis-Why not put them last? Mr Martin Ferguson-The Minister for Foreign Affairs is putting her last. Mr Latham-Put her last.

Speaker: Mr TIM FISCHER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: You raised the Hanson agenda. Let me, for the first time, say something about it. The member for Oxley is not here again today. I have to belt around the world, but I have still attended more divisions on actual legislation than the member for that, Oxley has attended in two years. In fact, I happen to have had the figures stored away. In 1996 and 1997-you might like to listen to this-there were 148 divisions on legislation, on actual bills on the floor of this parliament, excluding procedural votes and excluding gags. The member for Oxley missed 100 out of those 148 divisions. She was only present for 48 out of those 148 divisions. Whether you are for or against her particular agenda, her representation is worth about 32c in the dollar.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I ask that leave be given to table the Mr Reith-No.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Leave is not given. The member for Menzies has the call. Taxation

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House how the tax system creates disincentives to work?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, there are many things that are wrong with the present Australian taxation system, and I pointed out the weaknesses of the wholesale tax system which Labor embraces ferociously and wants to increase. Also, according to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, they want to engage in a bit of broadening. What he said at that doorstop yesterday, which was pointed out by the Acting Treasurer, is indeed illuminating. What he is really saying is that Labor's policy is to collect more money through the indirect taxation system. And is he going to use that to fund reductions in personal income tax?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: What rubbish!

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: He says, 'What rubbish!' The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says that you are going to engage in a bit of base broadening. Base broadening is a euphemism for saying that you are going to increase the level of indirect taxation. You cannot broaden the base without collecting more tax, and that is exactly what you have suggested. Mr Speaker, the member for Menzies asks me about the disincentive for work effects of the existing taxation system. I remind the member for Menzies that in 1954 the average wage earner paid 171h per cent tax on additional earnings. By 1998-99, a taxpayer on average earnings will move from the 34 per cent to the 43 per cent tax bracket. What that means is that, for every extra dollar you earn at the average wage level, you will pay 43c of that extra dollar in taxation. That is the system the Australian Labor Party wants to maintain. That means that if an Australian worker earns more than $728 a week-and there are many Australian workers who earn that-they will pay tax at a marginal rate of 43 per cent. And, what is more, if you happen to earn $950 a week, you will pay marginal rates of tax at the top rate of tax. The way the present system is going, by the year 2000 more than one-third of all Australian taxpayers will be earning more than $728 a week and will, therefore, without reform, face a marginal rate of tax which is greater than 40 per cent. So, by the year 2000, unless we reform the system, you will have one-third of all Australian taxpayers paying at the margin more than a 40 per cent rate of tax. That is yet another example of the impact on incentives to work of the present Australian taxation system. There is little doubt-as a result of the exchanges in this parliament of the last two days-that, just as the Labor Party is chained to the Maritime Union of Australia, it is also chained to the existing taxation system; just as the Australian Labor Party is chained to a system that produces a lopsided inequitable application of indirect tax, it is also chained to a system that brutally penalises Australian exporters. By contrast, the coalition is committed to reforming the Australian taxation system, to providing Australia with a system that supports Australian exporters, providing the Australian worker with a system that provides an incentive to work and, above all, provides to all Australians a system that is based on equity and fairness which will help contribute to the security, the stability and the safety of the Australian economy. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. NA

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I refer to the Sydney Morning Herald editorial which, coincidentally, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) referred to. In the course of that editorial, it is suggested that, in remarks that I made about the Liberal government's enrolment benchmark adjustment when I referred to it as encouraging sectarianism, that referred to the attitudes of particular schools. Any reading of my speech points out that that was not the case. The sectarianism I was referring to, as the speech makes explicitly clear, was the sectarianism that existed before the 1970s where there was a debate between the Catholic education system and the state school system which has been revived by the enrolment benchmark.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I was rising on the rules relative to personal explanations, but I might also draw to your attention anybody who rises in this fashion to get your attention. The Leader of the Opposition continues to make a speech, and with great speed, when he knows it is out of order, and I think it is time it was drawn to his attention.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: It has been on several occasions.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented? Mr GARETH EV ANS-Yes, by the foreign minister in question time today.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) alleged that, as foreign minister in 1993, I was culpably responsible for issuing Christopher Skase with a new passport. I make four short factual points in reply. Point one: I can find rio papers in my personal archives on this matter and I have no specific recollection of the matter ever coming to me from my department for information, advice or decision. I may be wrong in that recollection, but my belief is that the issue was resolved at departpoint mental level in consultation with A-Gs because of the second point I come to. The second point is that I do have a general recollection of discussing the issue with the Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, with whom I discussed many aspects of the Skase affair, and getting advice from him-it might have been from a member of my department but I think it was from Michael Lavarchthat, in the context of this case, neither my department nor I had any legally available discretion to refuse to issue the new passport sought in the absence of any arrest warrant being issued. Mr Downer-So you did discuss it.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I repeat: I have a general recollection of having discussed it with Michael Lavarch and being given the advice because the issue of a passport possibly being issued was a live one all year. If Foreign Affairs had refused to issue the passport, we would have immediately been challenged in the courts and ordered to issue the passport in question. The third factual point is that, despite efforts having been made throughout 1993 to get an arrest warrant issued, that did not occur until January 1994. It certainly was not the case at the time that the new passport was issued in July 1993. The final point I make is this: I note that neither the foreign minister today, nor Senator Vanstone yesterday, have claimed that either I or my department did in fact

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The deputy leader cannot now argue the case.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: This goes to the question of culpability, Mr Speaker. If you were accused of culpable behaviour, you would want to get it on the record as well. It is the final point I would make.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: In the course of a personal explanation, the deputy leader can only respond to matters where he has been personally misrepresented. I am listening very closely at the moment. He seems to be arguing the case.

Speaker: Mr GARETH EVANS
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I simply make the that it has not been claimed today or yesterday that I did have any legally available discretion that would have survived any scrutiny by the courts. In the absence of any such discretion, no possible question of culpability can arise. The foreign minister's statement should be seen for what it is-a crude and contrived political slur.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes, I do, on two occasions.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: On both occasions I was misrepresented by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith). On the first occasion, he referred to an interjection which I made yesterday during question time when the minister was continuing extreme provocation in relation to the question of Columbus Canada, which he said was still subject to a blockade off the west coast of the US. My interjection, as it appears in Hansard, was, 'Absolutely! The fight is against the scabs!' as it was and as it continues to be. If anyone wants to know anything about scabs, they can read my speech on the adjournment debate.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will conclude his personal explanation. He is not arguing the case.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: My concern is

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I am not interested in your concerns. I will hear your personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: My concern is for misrepresentation, Mr Speaker.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: You will personally respond.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I am indicating where I was misrepresented by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business on two occasions.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please do so.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The first one was the implication by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business that I resile from the interjection that I directed across there. It does not appear in Hansard, but I do not resile from it. What I do resile from is the implication that I had suggested or implied that that particular ship should sink and perhaps imperil seamen's lives. That was certainly not the import of my interjection. I have never wished any physical injury or danger to anyone and I certainly did not in connection with that. Not only that, but I withdraw unreservedly those remarks. The second way in which I have been misrepresented, again by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, was when he said I was in some way supporting a position, in relation to this question, which had been adopted by the Leader of the Opposition. I make it perfectly clear that the Leader of the Opposition repeatedly and firmly has said he has not, does not and will not endorse any embargo against Australian ships.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: What the Leader of the Opposition does is not your responsibility, as you would know.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.,

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the minister claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I claim to have been misrepresented by the claim of the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) that I misrepresented him. In support of my claim I quote from an AAP report

Speaker: Unknown
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I cannot hear anything at the moment. If members persist in intervening, we will have to suspend proceedings until we can hear the minister. The minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: To rebut the misrepresentation, I quote from the AAP report of yesterday marked 'Priority high' where it says: But Mr Brown, a junior transport minister in the early 19908 and now a backbencher. called outMr Bevis interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Brisbane will remain silent. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has just said that he wants to--

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: What is your point of order? Mr Leo MCLeay-I am about to tell you that.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Will you do so? Mr Leo MCLeay-He said he wants to rebut

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: What is your point of order? Mr Leo MCLeay-He said he wants to rebut what the member for Charlton said. That is not a personal explanation and maybe even you understand that.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will withdraw that implication against me. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, I do not see how you could have seen any implication because it was not meant.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member will withdraw that remark. Mr Leo MCLeay-I said it was not meant.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will withdraw that remark. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will withdraw that remark. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will withdraw that implication. Mr Leo MCLeay-Am I going to get time to do so or are you going to interrupt me all the time?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable member will withdraw that implication before I address the point of order. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Will you withdraw that implication? Mr Leo MCLeay-If I can get

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Are you going to withdraw that remark? Mr Leo MCLeay-Can I get two words out and I will.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: You have just got four words out and I have not heard you withdraw. Will you withdraw that remark? Mr Leo MCLeay-If you give me a moment, I will.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: You have now got six words out. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, if you take exception to that, I withdraw it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Thank you. I call the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: What about the point of order? Are you going to rule on the point of order?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I will. With respect to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, he will addressMr Martin Ferguson-Sit down and get back in your cell.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The member for Batman will remain silent. The member for Watson raised a point of order with respect to making a personal explanation. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr Speaker, is the minister going to resume his seat while you are addressing my point of order?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I think the honourable member would do well to resume his seat, too. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business will respond where he has been personally misrepresented.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I was misrepresented by the member for Charlton and I table the AAP report. NA National Reconciliation Week

Speaker: Mrs STONE
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, could you tell the House what steps have been taken by the parliament to recognise National Reconciliation Week-which begins tomorrow-and, in particular, how are we to communicate Reconciliation Week to the public?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I thank the honourable member who, I know, along with other members of this place, takes a particular interest in this matter. Dr Theophanous interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: The honourable member for Calwell might extend a bit of courtesy at times. There are a number of measures which have been taken. I mentioned the displaying of flags, both within the parliament and within the parliamentary precincts. In addition, a plaque commissioned by the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation in 1997 to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the 1967 Commonwealth referendum on Aborigines is on display outside the theatrette, where a number of ceremonies are taking place today. In addition, a publication has been prepared, in response to a question from the honourable member, on the artworks of indigenous Australians. It is an excellent publication and it will be distributed to all members. I table it for the purpose of the records of this House. Flags in the Chamber

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, on 12 May 1998, I asked you a question about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags. You kindly made a statement to the House yesterday and also sent me correspondence on 22 May. I acknowledge that and congratulate you on the protocols you have put in place. I understand, however, that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags that are being 110wn this week will not be rotated, as occurs with the Australian flag. I ask you, firstly, to consider the preservation of those two flags because they are the first two Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags that have been flown adjacent to the chamber. Perhaps they could be displayed in an appropriate place in the vicinity of Parliament House or, indeed, maybe even presented to ATSIC. Secondly, I ask that consideration be given on future occasions, such as in NAIDOC Week and, hopefully, in future reconciliation weeks, to the rotation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags on a daily basis similar what occurs with the Australian flag, so that we might then be able to present them to local government organisations and local communities to be flown on appropriate occasions.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I take note of the second part of the honourable member's question. There are, I gather, some problems with obtaining sufficient quantities of the flag, but I shall examine the process. With respect to the two flags now on display, it would be my intention that they should be flown for the next sitting fortnight-this week and next week. I had thought, as a number of members have asked for the flag, that it 'would be more appropriate that they be presented by the parHament to ATSIC, and that is my present intention. Newsletters: Guidelines  aware, members can utilise their printing entitlement in the Department of the House of Representatives printing office to have newsletters printed. Could you advise members of the guidelines regarding material that members can have printed and what specifically are not allowed to be printed as newsletters by the printing office.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I take on notice the honourable gentleman's question and I will respond to him and to all members in due course. Parliamentary Language

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, you were concerned today about the form of questions to the House. I draw your attention to the last question asked by the member for Dunkley when he asked the minister to 'update the House'. I would have thought that was an inappropriate and certainly incorrect use of language and therefore was out of order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: If that was so, the honourable gentleman should have raised the question at the appropriate time. Members' Rights

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: My second questo tion relates to three occasions in recent times when there have been purported quotations from members of the chamber to which members have taken exception. Mr Speaker, your response each time has been to say that they had a right, there was a process, subsequently to correct that. It would seem to me that the implication of that interpretation-I would like to put this on notice to you-is that people can falsely represent quotations on behalf of members, knowing them to be wrong, getting them on to the public record, and the only response available to a member in redress is a personal explanation subsequently, which is an entirely different form. I would suggest that that constitutes a serious breach of privilege and a serious weakening of the rights of members in the chamber.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: It is not for me to resolve dilemmas that the honourable member has with respect to the interpretation of standing orders unless they are raised immediately on the occasion when they occur. There are procedures and practices if you believe there is a breach of members' privileges or a breach of standing orders. In the present instance, it is not customary for questions to the Speaker to be a time to elucidate detail of that sort. I would suggest that if the honourable gentleman has concerns he raises them at the time that the particular matter arises.

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, the three occasions involved two from the member for Sydney and one from the member for Charlton. They were raised with you and that was your ruling. What I am seeking from you is a clarification of your ruling, because the interpretation is that people can be misquoted openly in the chamber with impunity, having taken exception to it at the time.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: You would know as well as anybody that there have been many occasions when individuals have felt that remarks made by others in this place are not accurate. There are appropriate procedures for personal explanations. They should be followed. Speaker: Rulings

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, on becoming a member of this House, I read closely the standing orders of the House. I have to say that I am a little confused at the present time. I am wondering what your ruling is not just on the framing of questions but also on speeches before questions and members who have been called to order, and the number of times people are named in this House before they lose the privileges of the House. Could you contemplate that and report back at a later date?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I know that the honourable member for Page is aware of a procedure in the New South Wales parliament where a person is warned twice and the third time they are automatically suspended. It is a procedure in practice that might have some advantage in this place the way some people are behaving at the moment. At the same time, I do understand that we are in a run-down to an election and a certain amount of heat, passion and enthusiasm are being generated. There are occasions in this place when it is impossible to hear. I suggest, for the benefit of all members, that it would be to their advantage if there was a little more silence while members are putting questions, making statements or responding to questions in this House. NA

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: BUSINESS
text: Mr Speaker, on indulgence, I have two matters. The first is to say something about the House arrangements and the second matter is to table papers as is usual. Mr Robert Brown-Put on your balac1ava.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: BUSINESS
text: The honourable member will remain silent.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: BUSINESS
text: I will start reading your speeches on the adjournment again if you are not careful.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: BUSINESS
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: BUSINESS
text: I made a few remarks a while ago about silence in this House. The next person who intervenes, I suggest, will be absenting himself or herself from the chamber for a while.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: BUSINESS
text: The arrangements are expected to be as follows. There have been discussions between the government and the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean) regarding the handling of bills and government business this week and next week. There are a very significant number of bills which need to be dealt with by the House due to various time limits, scheduling and the like. What we are attempting to doMr Adams interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: BUSINESS
text: I ask the member for Lyons to leave the House understanding order 304A. I told you that the next person to intervene would be required to leave. The honourable member will leave the House for one hour. The honourable member for Lyons thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: BUSINESS
text: We are attempting to ensure that we have reasonable opportunity for people to speak on all the matters but at the same time deal with the matters before us. To that end, whilst we do not as yet have an agreement about all the matters, I think it would be fair to say that we have in mind a general in-principle framework for this week and next week. I hope we will be able to come to an agreement about the details of that, but I can say to the House that, as part of this cooperative effort to manage the affairs of the House, it is intended that the HouseMs Macklin interjecting

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: BUSINESS
text: The member for Jagajaga will leave the House understanding order 304A for an hour. The honourable member for Jagajaga thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: BUSINESS
text: On this understanding, it is therefore intended that the House will sit tomorrow night, Wednesday night, but I think I can safely say it has been agreed with the Manager of Opposition Business-and I am sure the member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay) as well-that as we sit tomorrow night there will be no divisions or quorums so that everybody can have their opportunity to speak on the appropriation bills. In return for that magnanimous gesture-I would hope that we would have the support of the Independents for this sensible measure-it is proposed to have some discussion in the House on the appropriation bills. It will be limited to Thursday morning. The appropriation bills will then be sent off to the Main Committee. It will allow us to have more debate on the appropriation bills in the House than we had last year but not as much as the year before. I think that is a fair compromise. We have provided to the Manager of Opposition Business a long list of bills which we would like through next week. He has responded by saying, 'There's no way known that that lot can get through,' so we will attempt to cull that list on a reasonable basis to obviate the necessity to have a whole lot of time wasting divisions, gag motions and guillotines, which I can assure you we will have if we do not come to a sensible arrangement. That is where things are at. It does mean that we will sit tomorrow night. I presumewe have not as yet discussed this-there is a possibility that we will do the same next week to make sure that people have an opportunity to speak on bills, but we have not as yet had a chance to speak on those issues.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: BUSINESS
text: Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I wish to respond to the Leader of the House (Mr Reith). He has described the arrangement which was arrived at, but there is still some uncertainty about what that leaves us with next week. I make the point that what is proposed on the government's list after the appropriation bills is 21 bills in total and government business in a full sitting week allows for only 22 hours of debate. It is clearly beyond the realms of any possibility that 21 bills can be debated in 22 or 23 hours, depending on what is residual from Thursday. I suggest to the minister here, as I have over the phone, that he needs to do a fair bit of culling. He needs to take some particular note of where those bills that are left are contentious-and some are-because clearly some greater time for debate is going to be required in relation to them than others about which we might be able to get an agreement. In the absence of having yet got that list culled down, we are not in a position to indicate further agreement. But I am pleased to note that the Leader is offering the possibility of sitting on the Wednesday night. Let us see the list, and let us have some genuine discussion on it. NA
