Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: I seek leave to move a motion concerning Sorry Day in the terms that we have discussed with the government. Mr Reith-The government agrees to consent to the application for leave on the basis of the discussions that have proceeded between both sides. The member for Bass will respond for the government in due course. There will be a motion from the Leader of the Opposition and there will be an amendment motion from the government. It is intended that there will be two speakers a side in the normal way vis a vis a matter of public importance.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: I move: That: Members of this House, on the occasion of Australia's first Sorry Day, place on record their concern for the policies enforced by earlier governments that separated Aboriginal children from their parents, producing a fundamental denial of their human rights and causing untold human suffering. Notwithstanding that in some instance these policies were well motivated they nevertheless had the effect of separating children from their parents and deprived them of their right to be reared within their own families, denying them a knowledge of their culture and traditions. For that, we Members of this Parliament apologise and express the deepest regret for the pain and suffering caused to our fellow Aboriginal citizens. We apologise for the mistakes of the past, believing such an apology is the first step to effective reconciliation. We also place on record our indebtedness to Sir Ronald Wilson and the members of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission whose painstaking work in their report brought this evidence before the Parliament and the Australian people, and in so doing provided this nation with the opportunity of rectifying past wrongs and building a positive relationship amongst all Australian citizens. As the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) indicated, the government will move an amendment later to that motion, and the way in which it moves that amendment will supplant the motion. I think that is unfortunate. If it were to move as an amendment an addendum to the motion, even though it is full of self-congratulation, which we would not necessarily consider justified, we would accept it and we would have been able to have as an addendum to this motion a unanimous resolution from this House. It is a pity that that will not occur. The motion that we have proposed has been carefully crafted. It has been carefully crafted to take into account the sorts of concerns that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has portrayed--concerns, of course, which in terms of their legal content and argument we do not accept and which are not consistent with advice that we had at the time when these were matters of consideration before us. Certainly they are legal considerations which have not concerned the conservative premiers of most of the states of this country who have allowed motions of substance to go forward in relation to an apology and atonement for past wrongs done to the Aboriginal people which were exposed in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. Nevertheless, we removed from our motion anything that could be inferred as accepting a sense of legal responsibility that might in some way cause occasion for government lawyers to be concerned when these matters go to court. We also removed from our motion an obligation on all members of parliament, and the parliament as a whole, to offer an apology. We made a sincere effort to put a motion in the context that I would have thought was the minimum acceptable position for the government or anyone else .. As I said, we are even prepared to accept the government's self-congratulatory amendment as an addendum to the proposition that we have put forward in our efforts to ensure that something comes out of this House that actually reflects the level of concern which I know members on both sides of this House feel. It would have been of a piece, I would say, Mr Speaker, with the excellent work that you yourself have done over the course of this week to ensure that appropriate opportunities are provided both to recognise the importance of reconciliation and to allow within the precincts of this parliament various forums in which Sorry Day can be appropriately reflected upon by both members of parliament and the public generally. It is a shame that your good effort and our, I might say, liberality have not been recognised in the final instance by the government in that our motion and the government's as an addendum will not now be the motions that are ultimately passed by this parliament. Because there has been a degree of criticism of this and a degree of concern in the community, I note the anxiousness of those who have involved themselves in the Sorry Day process to put forward the basis on which they are approaching this issue in the community as not being about individual gUilt or the apportionment of blame. Whatever might have been in that report, there is an anxiousness in their community to move the issue on from the point reached when the report was first put in place. They are anxious to have us move forward together as a nation, starting from an honest and open appraisal of our history. A,ny honest and accurate history of relations between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians reveals events, attitudes, actions and policies that should be the cause of shared regret, shared sorrow and a common purpose in seeing that such things are not perpetuated or repeated. That same history, with its consistent thread of dispossession, destruction of indigenous culture and heritage, and the deliberate fracture of indigenous families, should inform and illuminate our understanding of present day despair and social dysfunction in our indigenous communities. We cannot frame better policies if we fail to address the underlying fallacies and prejudices of past policies, whether or not anyone in this chamber-and virtually no-one is-is responsible for any of them. It is a cop-out to say that we cannot or should not evaluate our past policies or actions according to contemporary values and attitudes. The fact is that virtually every evil of public policy and administrative action directed towards indigenous Australians was the subject of informed and widespread contemporary criticism. The Roth Royal Commission in Western Australia in 1905 provided one of the first systematic critiques and was followed by, among others, the Finnerty report of 1908 and the 1935 Moseley report. Those reports challenged the sorts of policies that produced ultimately the report which we refer to in the motion. The cautionary point for every legislature today is that every aspect of past policies for which we now express regret was framed in the context of contemporary debate that clearly showed that it was widely criticised at the time. Perhaps those legislators were content to march forward safely with majority public opinion rather than accept informed but less popular advice. It is broadly accepted that the practice of removing indigenous children from their families continued until recent times-recent enough to encompass the early careers in public life of some who are still in this place. For many people this can only be dealt with with any degree of comfort by consigning mistakes to some ill-defined past. One guarantee that mistakes will be repeated is to accept comforting myths. In 1949, we ratified UN conventions that dealt precisely with the forcible transfer of children from one group to another and dealt precisely with imposing measures intended to prevent births within a group. So these policies were continued for a lengthy period of time against a background of that convention which Australia was actively engaged in designing but which, nevertheless, governments of the day chose to ignore them. Public policy across the nation proceeded either in ignorance or defiance of that convention for the best part of a generation after its ratification. It is equally dangerous policy for policy makers to comfort themselves with the myth that, even when a policy was not done for the good of separated children, the net effect was itself good. If we go beyond incidental anecdotes to scientific research on this question, the myth is very quickly disposed of. Recent studies show that a comparison of educational attainment, income level and employment status between indigenous Australians separated from their families and those who were not demonstrates consistently better outcomes for those who stayed with their families. This is scientific research, not anecdotal evidence. Sadly, the statistics go in the other direction when we look at the negative outcomes. One of the findings of the inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody-a finding that was a key motivation for the stolen children report-was that those who had been separated from their families were overrepresented amongst deaths in custody. It is not surprising that individuals denied parental and family love and support, education in their first language and who were separated from their own culture would suffer social and psychological problems in later life. The fact that many of them also suffered systematic physical, mental and sexual abuse was a dominant influence in their personal development, their ability to form relationships and their capacity to function in a society ·often hostile or indifferent to them. That is another point I would make about that excellent report that Sir Ronald Wilson brought down and which our motion acknowledges. Unquestionably, in the Australian community there are many families who looked after Aboriginal children in an absolutely impeccable fashion. But that report also demonstrated that there are many instances, either in relation directly to families or more generally in relation to institutions, where what was experienced by Aboriginal children was criminal---<:riminal in the context of the times, not criminal by some form of hindsight. It has never been a matter supported by the law in this country that you should be permitted to rape or enslave people. That has never been sanctioned by Australian law at any point of time in our history, yet repeated instances of that are pointed to in that Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. It has never been a matter sanctioned by the law that a position of authority should be used to permit sexual or other forms of abuse-never has that been sanctioned by the law in this nation at any point of time in our history-yet the report is replete with instances of where that occurred. Of course, in that regard, as we have in melancholy fashion occasion to know, not only Aboriginal children but other children in the care of the state or other institutions have experienced a similar method of treatment. That is similarly illegal and their experiences are now the subject of inquiry, compensation and a whole range of other activities in terms of counselling to deal with the problems that they have confronted. But the difference between the Aboriginal community and the other sections of the community that have experienced this is that, in the case of the Aboriginal community, there was a pattern of government decision which produced the set of circumstances in a way that uniquely applied to the race. So what may have been in other areas of the community haphazard instances of abuse in the case of the Aboriginal community started out from a fundamental point that a policy needed to be pursued towards the Aboriginal community in a manner which would place them at a degree of risk. On this, our first Sorry Day, those who cannot bring themselves to apologise for past wrongs should at least be able to express sorrow and empathy with such widely documented personal and family tragedy. I have given up trying to get an apology out of the Prime Minister on these matters. It is not possible to get it. In one sense, of course, if you do not actually mean an apology, it is not worth making it. At the end of the day, if you do not actually mean it-and that does not just apply to the Prime Minister, it applies to anyone else-it is not worth making. We all have to live in this community. We all have to live with the consequences of actions. We all want a united community. At least there is room in the hearts of all of us to express sorrow to and empathise with those who have experienced the experiences of those Aboriginal families who were separated in the way in which that report deals with. Policy makers who fear history, who are unable to honestly evaluate what went wrong and why it went wrong, I am afraid to say, are doomed to repeat it. One commentator said today that the expenditure measures the Prime Minister is about to make are better and more useful than any apology. I beg to differ. While any clawback of the massive cuts the government has visited upon programs for indigenous Australians is welcome, it is a mistake to identify the problems of indigenous communities as being primarily or exclusively defined in terms of material poverty. Policies that fail to appreciate and address the personal and social dysfunction that has flowed from past and present injustices are policies that will not succeed. Just as policy makers of other generations were wrong in their paternalistic conviction that things needed to be done to or for indigenous Australians for their own good, so we will fail today if our policies are ill-informed and enacted for rather than with indigenous Australians. In our sorrow today for indigenous Australians, let us also mourn our common loss. Let us acknowledge that we are all the poorer for the generations of neglect and denial-the denial of opportunities that has robbed us of more Michael Dodsons, more Cathy Freemans, more Lois O'Donoghues, more Harold Blairs-and I could go on with a list of distinguished Australians. Ignorance blinded us until only recently to the magnificence and richness of indigenous art, dance, song and stories, and prejudice determined that desecration and suppression rather than celebration were the hallmarks of many responses to so much that is rich, strong and spiritually uplifting. It is in the interests of reconciliation, a more mature national identity and sound public policies that members of this parliament open their eyes, their ears and their hearts. The motion that we have moved gives them an opportunity to open their eyes, their ears and their hearts. I have, on several occasions-once in this place-apologised for the Labor Party's role in this sorry tale. I offer that apology again here today. But I acknowledge that it is now incumbent upon the Labor Party, at the state and federal levels, when we were responsible for those activities, to now also bear the responsibility to see that the consequences of them are cured. Important though these questions are, the curing of that goes well beyond the material dealing with the problem, the issues of expenditure. They go to the attitude that is created in the community. Are we going to be a community that exploits the opportunity for division, exploits the opportunity for difference, or are we going to be a community that uses the value of unity? We may judge ourselves one way, but others will judge us a different way . We may judge past policies as something that we cannot come to grips with or not be obliged to come to grips with. Others will judge us differently. Others are capable of being inspired by us or making us a cause. If we do not comprehend in the process that the deculturalisation of a large number of members of our Aboriginal community and the acceptance of that was what underpinned the wrong, if we do not understand that, we cannot really come to grips with why native title is so important to the Aboriginal community. If we cannot understand that a sense of loss of culture, a sense of loss of personal sovereignty, fundamentally underlies much of the dysfunction that exists in large elements of the Aboriginal community, we cannot understand the necessity for policies which apply a cultural underpinning to the life that is led by the Aboriginal community. It will make us indifferent to the outcomes in so many critical areas of public policy and will doom us to repeat the errors of the past. I do not want to canvass here the grounds that have underpinned the debate between us on both sides of the House of that Wik legislation. I do not want to canvass the reasons why there needs to be incorporated in any solution to it a right to negotiate. We are going to have plenty of opportunity to do that, unfortunately, in the course of the next few months. But my concern is that there is a thorough comprehension in the parliament and in the community of what underpins a person's sense of cultural confidence or what underpins, in particular, the Aboriginal community's sense of cultural confidence. We will never be able to overcome that family dysfunction, we will never be able to overcome that Aboriginal dysfunction, unless there is recognised by the laws of this nation a complete and comprehensive appreciation of the culture and the nature of the indigenous people who are here before us and have so recently had the rights that are attached to that recognised by the highest court in our land.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: I move: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "this House: 0) recognises the need for the legislative and other powers of the Commonwealth to be used to address the profound economic and social disadvantage continuing to be suffered by indigenous Australians-with specific emphasis on health, housing, education and employment; (2) notes that this Government is spending almost $1.9 billion in 1998-99 on indigenous specific programmes particularly targeted at these priority areas; (3) supports the reconciliation process as being important to all Australians and recognises the need to acknowledge past injustices, and emphasises the value of a cooperative effort to build a better future for all Australians; and (4) notes this Govcrnment's commitment to addressing the recommendations of the Bringing them home report through a $63m package of initiatives to assist in family reunion. I appreciate that the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was delivered with sincerity and I think many of us in this country would find ourselves in broad agreement with the sentiments he expressed today. I might say that they were expressed eloquently. I have to say that I find myself in an interesting position today. The usual representative for these matters is not here and this is the first occasion that r have had to speak on Aboriginal affairs in this place for nearly 10 years. I was at one stage the shadow minister for this area and listening to this debate made me cast my mind back. This is a day which does lead to personal reflection on these issues, so I will take this opportunity presented to me to express some personal views, which r think is appropriate in this particular debate. When I was the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs in the late 1980s, we had a major debate in this country about the establishment of the ATSIC legislation. The debates then, as they are now, were partisan in part but there was, as I think there is now, a fundamental commitment to wanting to address in a very practical way the needs of indigenous Australians. That is the intent of the motion that we have moved today as a substitution. Our motion looks at the practical ways in which we can assist indigenous Australians. The issues that I faced then were always a matter of budget, as they are now, but it was always an issue of how you got the money to the people who needed it most. That indeed was a chalIenge for the last government, as it is for this government. Whilst I believe that, broadly, in this place and in the community we share very similar sentiments about the need to address disadvantages-which has been demonstrated by both sides of politics through many reports-there was a specific report that highlighted this issue and led to the motion by the Leader of the Opposition today. That was Sir Ronald Wilson's report, Bringing them home. I did not have the opportunity to bring my own copy of this report, which I had annotated, into the chamber today. Being the minister in this government responsible for families and also childrenand that covers all families and all childrenwhen I received this report I was struck by its front page and the extract which had particular meaning and resonance to me. The very first quotation-and I am going to read it to the House, and it is lengthy-relates to an area which, by coincidence, is in my electorate. I know the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) will appreciate this point, as will the member for Braddon (Mr Miles). The area is Cape Barren Island. The state of Tasmania has a significant history in relation to Aboriginal issues, and I think it would be universally agreed that most of it is an appalling one. The Bringing them home report starts with a quotation from a submission made by one of eight siblings who were removed from their families and fostered separately. It is a particularly poignant quotation and reads as follows: So the next thing I remember was that they took us from there and we went to the hospital and I kept asking-because the children were screaming and the little brothers and sisters were just babies course, and I couldn't move, they were all around me, around my neck and legs, yelling and screaming. 1 was all upset and I didn't know what to do and I didn't know where we were going. I just thought: well, they're police, they must know what they're doing. I suppose I've got to go with them, they're taking me to see Mum. You know this is what I honestly thought. They kept us in hospital for three days and I kept asking, 'When are we going to see Mum?' And no-one told us at this time. And I think on the third or fourth day they piled us in the car and r said, 'Where are we going?' And they said, 'We are going to see your mother'. But then we turned left to go to the airport and I got a bit panicky about where we were going ... They got hold of me, you know what I mean, and I got a little baby in my arms and they put us on the plane. And they still told us we were going to see Mum. So I thought she must be wherever they're taking us. Of course, that was not the case. When I read the elements of the Bringing them home report, I reflected on the deaths in custody reports that I read as shadow minister, and the Leader of the Opposition referred to them. Honourable members would remember that, when those reports came out, there were sequential reports and small volumes. I read many of those at the time and was struck also by the fact that, when you had a separation early in the life of the child, the increase in the incidence of difficulties faced laterwhether it be by way of incarceration or selfmutilation, and many of the reports were graphic and certainly extremely disturbingwas clearly apparent. What I want to do is paint the picture. I do not think there is a person in Austral i a who would not regret what has happened in this country in the past. Indeed, we saw that as a nation we ignored the 1949 convention for over a generation. But what we are discussing today is what we do about these issues in a practical sense. So I would hope that the parliament and the nation are not going to divide on semantic arguments but accept the spirit of what is being said here today. The view that I want to articulate is that our future actions must be illuminated by the history that we know. If we can all take account of that history and look positively for practical ways to assist indigenous Australians, I think that indigenous Australians and all of us, both of now and in the future, will be better for that endeavour. The National Sorry Day was a recommendation from the Bringing them home report. The day has been privately organised, and we say thank you to those who have been involved. It is not a government initiative, and participation is a matter for individuals. There is no doubt, however, that some people are uncomfortable with the concept of a sorry day or have trouble relating to it. It would be a pity if people were turned away from Reconciliation Week because of that. Reconciliation Week is very strongly supported by the government. Both the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and my colleague Dr Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs-and, I might say, a very compassionate and understanding individual who is universally acclaimed for the work he is doing in this area of difficult public policy-have expressed their personal regret over the treatment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians in the past. Indeed, I have done so, and do so again today. If other Australians want to express their regrets for those actions by signing sorry books, then that is clearly a matter for those individuals. As I say, we want to take practical steps. When I was the shadow minister in the late 1980s, we sought ways to take practical steps. We still seek ways to take practical steps, and each Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs will take steps to ensure that there are practical outcomes. The response by the government to the Bringing them home report was to make very substantial funds available to help those who have been affected to trace their families. If, the centrepiece of being is an attachment to family, as I think it is, and if you have been taken from your family-like that young child from Cape Barren Island in the middle of Bass Strait, as isolated an area as any in our nation-and you believe you want assistance to trace your family, then we as a nation should provide it, and we have done so. We will provide counselling, as we are doing at the present time, for those who need support. That is a practical step. It is a sensible step and one on which the government enjoys congratulations from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. We have also wanted to substantially focus on the issue of health. I know that, as health minister, my colleague Dr Wooldridge, who succeeded me as shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, established an indigenous health unit in his department when he had the opportunity on coming to government. I know that the former minister for health, who was here a moment ago, would echo the need for that. We want the unit to focus on the need to improve health outcomes in Aboriginal communities. We have provided an extra $73 million over the next three years. Dr Herron has taken some innovative steps. Something we have not done before is engage the Army to assist in remote areas to improve such basic things as water. These are the things that I think we need to recognise as having to be done. In fact, they are being done. We want to tackle those key issues. They are not matters that you need to keep talking about; they are matters that require action. Too often in the past we have talked too much and we have not done enough. So I come back to my fundamental point: in our future and current actions we need to be illuminated by the history that we now know that has been brought to our attention by the deaths in custody report and the Bringing them home report. On the issue of reconciliation, I believe the government has clearly demonstrated that it strongly supports Reconciliation Week and the process of reconciliation. Indeed, the announcement by the Speaker, before the commencement of this debate, is to be commended. We believe that there are basically three essential matters that need to considered. There needs to be a mutual acceptance of the importance of working together and ensuring that our differences do not prevent us from sharing equality and a common future. I think we can all agree with that. Second, there needs to be an honest and realistic acknowledgment of the injustices of the past. I am sure each of us can provide anecdotal examples from our own reading, from our own representations from constituents, and from other knowledge, of how we can address those injustices of the past. Indeed, the churches, who played a very central role, have recognised that they have a key moral role to play in dealing with the future needs of indigenous Australians. Third, there needs to be a shared commitment to overcoming indigenous disadvantage and providing equality of opportunity for all Australians. They are the three points that must lead us forward in the reconciliation debate. They must lead to justice and equity for all indigenous Australians, wherever they might be. As I travelled the length and breadth of Australia in the late 1980s, I certainly found that I was personally enriched by viewing the diversity of culture that exists from the Torres Strait to Elcho Island, Western Australia, South Australia, and my own state of Tasmania. I am proud to say that this government has taken some practical steps. And that is what we seek to illustrate today by way of this amendment. We recognise the centrality of land to Aboriginal culture, and we are dealing with those issues. We have a special unit for health. We are dealing with the need for employment opportunities. We are dealing with the problem of disproportionate incarceration, particularly of young Aboriginal males in custody. All of these issues can be seen to have taken a marked move forward. I would hope that all in this chamber would recognise those moves for what they are. It is progress. It is what is needed for indigenous Australians. If we can unite on one thing today, we should unite on a view of the need to illuminate policies for now and for the future by what we know of the past. Let us not repeat the mistakes of the past. I am personally sorry for what has happened, but we as a nation must go forward. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: The Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith), who is at the table and who has just finished an important speech on behalf of the government, finished on the basis of saying that he was sorry for what occurred. If one looks at the motion moved by the government, one can say that there is nothing there which does not live quite comfortably with the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). I accept the fact that the minister, who in no way is responsible for any of these events that we are talking about, does feel sorry. I accept and believe that many of the members of the government would have no problem about expressing their sense of sorrow. I take it one stage further, Minister. I would say on this issue that if we as a parliaWe're ment are going to say anything of importance to our indigenous people, we should say it with one voice. There is nothing in the government's amendment which does not live comfortably with what has been put by the Leader of the Opposition. I believe it is in the interests of our indigenous people and it is in the interests of this parliament to speak clearly on this issue with a united voice, and we start by saying sorry. We often forget that when the First Fleet arrived in Australia every tree, every rock and every piece of bush was owned. It was part of an ongoing civilisation, a culture with a set of spiritual beliefs which were related to the land. If one makes a world comparison, one can say that those who settled this country were probably less brutal than those in other parts of the world in dealing with our indigenous people. But what we are dealing with here is a set of government decisions which not only got it wrong but also, in getting it wrong, has affected people who are still living in our community in a very real way. Let me quote from one Aboriginal mother from the evidence she gave to the commission as a result of being stolen. We continually hear in the parliament the emphasis that we as a parliament and the government as a government put on family values. What occurred in this case was that the concept of family was totally destroyed. I ask the mothers in this parliament how they would have felt if a police van arrived and their children were being taken on a picnic, or with any excuse, without the force of the law, taken illegally and were not to be seen again. That is what happened time and time again. How do we redress this wrong, because what is the effect? Let us look at just one piece of evidence given by an Aboriginal woman to the commission. She said: That's another thing that we find hard is giving our children love. Because we never had it. So we don't know how to tell our kids that we love them. All we do is protect them. I can't even cuddle my kids 'cause I never ever got cuddled. The only time was when I was getting raped and that's not what you'd call a cuddle, is it? Do we just say, 'We're going to fix that up. going to throw lots of money at it'? Compare the position that has been taken in this House today by the government with that which has been taken by the churches. Many of the churches were deeply involved in the administration of this policy and many of them were invoJved in the abuse of Aboriginal people. Do the bishops and the leaders of the churches walk away and say, 'Oh, well, we've got to get some money and fix this up'? They do not. That should be the first thing they understand. For those people who are of a religious belief in this parliament, part of the great Christian tradition of at least one major church is that before you can get forgiven you have to confess your wrongs. These were not the wrongs of this government. They were not the wrongs of our government, but we got it wrong. Aboriginal citizens right throughout Australia are living with this on a daily basis. It is not so hard. An apology is not so hard. I was confronted with that in a reconciliation meeting in my own electorate. As a result of reading this report, I realised that when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs one of the things I had not done as effectively as I would have wanted was that I did not give enough funding to an organisation called Link Up. If I had the knowledge that is contained in this report, I would have seen that they got a lot more money. I felt the need to publicly, in my own electorate, in the presence of Aboriginal people, get up and say, 'Look, I apologise. I'm sorry.' If I knew then as minister what I know now, I would have directed a lot more resources to this group. What was the response of the Aboriginal spokesman that followed me? Was it to say, 'Hah, hah, see, you got it wrong'? No, he got up and said to us, 'We thank you for the apology but we also thank you for all the things that you got right.' I would like the minister to think about that. We are in the situation where there are divisions within the Liberal Party on this issue. The state Liberal governments have had no difficulty in coming forward with apologies. What problem bedevils the Prime Minister? I suspect that, if we were crossing the chamber and he accidentally bumped into me, he would have no problem in saying sorry. What is the hang-up when you know that there are Aboriginal people living now who are totally dislocated in terms of their family and who continue to suffer, and when we as a parliament cannot bring ourselves to say, 'We regret that these things have occurred and we are sorry they ever happened'? The minister virtually said he is sorry. He does not have a problem. So where is the problem? Is it with the Prime Minister? If it is, let him tell us why it is so. We have had a fairly divisive and exciting day in this chamber today. But this is one issue where we as members of parliament can speak with one voice. We should begin by saying, 'We are sorry for a policy which denied Aboriginal citizens their human rights, which dislocated families and which was based on current racist concepts at the time.' The theory was very simple-everybody knew it-Aboriginal people were going to die out. If they are going to die out, what do you do? You grab the kids and you make them into little white people. I have a friend in the Northern Territory, a distinguished Aboriginal artist, who is of light skin. He can tell you in detail how, when the police van came round, his mother kept a tin of nugget that she would bring out and put on his face. He was then thrown under a pile of blankets and told not to move. I have never met an Aboriginal person who has not made an effort to find their family. I know of a distinguished Aboriginal woman who has achieved great academic distinction, and she tried to find her family. But what happens to an Aboriginal woman when her kids are taken from her? What would happen to any of the women in this parliament if their kids were taken from them never to be seen again? When this Aboriginal woman met her mother, her mother had become a hopeless alcoholic. How do you rejoin the bonds that have been snapped and broken? How do we as members of the parliamentwe have got kids of our own-not embrace the standards that have been taken by Christian and other religious leaders? We begin by saying, 'Look, we are sorry it happened. We profoundly regret it,' and then we get on with it. Unless the government can give us some explanation of that I do not believe individual government members and I do not believe this minister have any great difficulty with our motion-let us for once in the lifetime of this government get it right; let us add your amendment to our motion. Mrs Crosio-As an addendum.

Speaker: Mr HOLDING
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: As an addendum. Let us speak to our indigenous people on the basis that this parliament is united in providing not only money but also a view of them-their culture and their spiritual beliefs-that reinforces the family values which are so often talked about in this place. What does it cost? It does not cost the government anything, and it will bring some credit to the government in an election year. But, more importantly, it will bring some credit to this parliament when we as a continuum government start by saying to our indigenous Australians, 'We profoundly regret what happened.' This government has no problem because it was not involved. Our government has had no problem. But what we are saying is that, when a government gets it wrong in the history and in the continuum of government processes, it is up to us as members of the national parliament to give a lead by saying, 'We are sorry that this ever occurred. It shouldn't have. We're going to get it right.' We start by saying, 'Sorry, it shouldn't have happened,' and then we move on. The process has then begun of bringing our indigenous people more firmly into the bonds of our broader community so that their contribution to the future of this country will be secure. Make no mistake about it, the indigenous people's relationship with their land, their spiritual beliefs and the way they relate to each other provide very important aspects of our multicultural society. If we want to talk about a multicultural society-and we always do-let us now start focusing on the rights of our indigenous Australian people and on bringing them through these processes. We do that by saying, 'We are sorry. We are going to fix it up.' It is not a question of throwing money at the indigenous people. Any minister for Aboriginal affairs will tell you of the complexities of this portfolio. r have defended this minister on more than one occasion, because any minister has to be given a go. But the time has come when this parliament should speak with one voice and when we should unite around both these proposals rather than, in an election year, tum this aspect of the matter into yet another divisive political debate.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: First, in a personal sense, may I say that of course I very much regret what has occurred. The nature of this debate, essentially, has been constrained, and this is welcome in an area of great difficulty and complexity. The history of this country led to a situation in which our first migrants-or original inhabitants-were left very margin ali sed in a community that expected an assimilationist approach. It was an approach that has occasioned a great deal of difficulty. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), in his comments, wanted to make it appear as if this was a profoundly different issue to children being removed from parents. I do not wish to make it a debating point, save to say that I think there are, in our history, numbers of situations in which, for cultural reasons and for other reasons, children have been removed from parents and placed in institutional care. As a society, we still have to grapple with many of those questions. There are organisations in my own state that are particularly anxious about the situation of young people who have been placed in institutional care and subjected to abuse. There is very much an awareness of these issues emerging today. Equally, in the portfolio area for which I have responsibility, we fund an organisation that deals with young people who were removed from family situations. Many of these young people believed they were orphans but, as we now find out, this may not have been the case. Well-meaning organisations supported these actions, believing they were providing appropriate care and support. These young people were given admission under migration programs supported by govemments over a long period of time. We look back on this and we say that if we were to judge it by today's standards and what we now know, we would have treated it very differently. The outcome of policies and programs that were pursued by our forebears has had quite a significant impact upon this nation but a far greater impact upon the people concerned and their descendants. It is well known that Aboriginals suffer very significant disadvantage within our community. That is the reason why we have so many programs that are trying to address what we recognise as that significant disadvantage. These programs are not new. Programs have been developed for as long as I have been in public life. I served on Aboriginal affairs committees where we agonised about the way in which those programs would be implemented and the extent to which they would be successful. We saw a number of approaches which people suggested at different times would have an impact. I can remember moving to the situation of giving Aboriginals the right of self determination and self-management in the way moneys were spent on their behalf. That has developed to its greatest extent now, where most of the moneys are handed over to the Aboriginal managed and controlled organisation, ATSIC. We have seen an emphasis upon land rights-first recognised in the Northern Territory-in legislation put through by the Liberal government of the 1970s under Malcolm Fraser. There was an expectation that with land rights the situation would change remarkably. Now we see the emphasis is on apology and reconciliation. People generously want to support an approach which involves reconciliation. The government also puts a great deal of emphasis upon it. It does so in the context of mutual acceptance of the importance of working together to ensure that differences do not prevent us from sharing equally in a common future for this nation. There needs to be an honest and realistic acknowledgment of injustices of the past. There needs to be a shared commitment to overcoming indigenous disadvantage and providing equality of opportunity for all Australians. It is that socio-economic disadvantage suffered by our indigenous Australians that the government believes is its key priority. We target expenditure to identified areas of greatest need-health, housing, education and employment. If you go through each of these areas you can see--coming from very difficult and very significant disadvantagethat there have been, over time, some changes. I sometimes feel emboldened by the extent to which Aboriginals are so much more articulate today in putting their views about what should happen. I can remember earlier points in time when I felt that Aboriginals were, in a real sense, sometimes deprived of the capacity, courage, or perseverance to argue in their own cause. I now sometimes feel I will not say embarrassed but almost as one feels when somebody has abused one with a very strong and convincing argument. I feel very taken aback at the extent to which Aboriginals can now articulate their case and what they are seeking. I think the reason for this has a lot to do with what we have been able to achieve in education. It is important, in the context of the motion and the amendment that we are putting today, to recognise that Commonwealth funding for indigenous-specific programs has not only continued to increase but also now represents something of the order of $1.9 billion. When we look at ATSIC, we see an increase in 1997-98 of some $60 million over four years, with its level of funding guaranteed in all of that time. In the health area, we have seen in this year's budget something like $168 million is to be allocated to indigenous specific health programs. That represents a real increase of 37 per cent since 1995-96. Extra funding was provided in the 1996-97 budget over three years for the establishment of 35 new or expanded health services, with priority for remote and rural areas. In this budget, an additional $73 million over the next four years has been allocated to improve indigenous primary health care. In the housing area, in this budget $387 million will be spent on indigenous specific housing and infrastructure programs. In November 1996 the government announced an initiative involving the army providing urgently needed housing and infrastructure developments, including water and sewerage systems, in seven remote indigenous communities. Of course, that is also helping to ensure that skills in construction and ongoing maintenance are transferred to the communities involved. Interestingly, I gather those communities involved have been very responsive to those initiatives with our armed forces. In the area of education, funding for indigenous education programs will be $333 million this year. I was astounded to learn that today there are some 7,461 indigenous students in higher education. In 1998-99, $21.8 million will be provided under indigenous support funding programs to provide academic preparation, counselling and study centres within our universities. This recognises that sometimes, without lowering standards, there needs to be the capacity to help young people through their courses of study with peer support and special counselling. My own daughter is at the Australian National University. For a time she tutored students in courses of study that she was undertaking or had previously undertaken. I know that most of our universities are now providing those special arrangements to help Aboriginals through our educational system. That will lead to a very significant change in the future. When I think back to the time. I was at university, you could perhaps count on two hands the number of students who would come through with university degrees. We have relied very heavily upon some of those people, such as Charles Perkins and so on, who obtained a university degree many years ago. But they were singular examples. Today, we have 7,461 potential Aboriginal graduates. In the area of employment and economic development, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation, which facilitates and promotes joint venture arrangements between industry, the Commercial Development Corporation and indigenous people, is to be allocated an additional $10 million to top up its capital base. The government's other indigenous specific programs include new indigenous business incentive programs which provide seed funding, training and other support for newly established businesses for indigenous Australians. Of the order of $33 million will be provided for these in 1998-99. One area about which I have always been impressed-I think it was, probably, if you wanted to use the term, the first work for the dole arrangement in Australia-is the community development employment program. With indigenous people there is an unemployment rate that is four times that of the general population, but this scheme enables our indigenous people to forgo rights to unemployment benefits and undertake work on community projects which will benefit them. Those community projects have been protected from any form of expenditure reduction. In fact, they were expanded to a total funding, in 1998-99, of $402 million for 33,083 participants. That scheme is one which I know gives Aboriginals an opportunity to be involved in maintaining their homes, the environment in which they are living and their communities, and it provides them with self-esteem. Rather than getting what I think was often colloquially referred to as 'sit down' money, they are able to say, 'I have worked for these particular funds that I am being paid.' We have put these arrangements in place in the context of ensuring that Aboriginal programs will be free from criticism. In the past, one has been prepared, perhaps, to forgo the opportunity to effectively audit and ensure that accountability arrangements are in place. One way of ensuring that these programs are well supported is to ensure that the community recognises that they are accountable and, especially, worked. My colleague the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) fully supported the Commonwealth initiatives when he outlined them in relation to the response to the Bringing them home report. I am pleased that this debate has not been acrimonious but has been positive. We look forward to support for our amendment from the opposition. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: It causes me considerable pain, and to some extent grief, to participate in this debate today for reasons which I now outline. I find the motion by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) to be eminently supportable. It is interesting that in their contributions the two government ministers-the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock)-have not attempted to argue in any way against the motion. Both of them are decent individuals and amongst the better of the government ministers. Deep down, I think they would be wanting to support this motion. Mr Fitzgibbon-In contrast to the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: It is sad for me that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has not seen fit or felt able to participate in this debate. I believe he should have. This debate is very important. As the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs said, it does not have to be acrimonious; nevertheless, it is an important debate-important enough, I would have thought, for the Prime Minister to have participated. I feel very sad that he has chosen not to do so. The Minister for Family Services said the debate is about semantics, but it is not. The motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition strikes at the very core of this issue. In his motion, the Leader of the Opposition said that an apology is the first step to effective reconciliation. That is the crux of this debate. That is not semantics; that is something which I believe is supportable. The government ministers who spoke said that Reconciliation Week is supported by the government-'strongly supported', the Minister for Family Services said-but by its actions here today it has demonstrated otherwise. I was also disappointed by the Prime Minister's answer in question time on this issue where he indicated, yet again, his intention not to apologise. I take the Leader of the Opposition's point that it is now too late for an apology-it would be hollow and meaningless. I think it is pointless to continue to expect or to ask that the Prime Minister should apologise on behalf of the government, this parliament or the people of Australia. That opportunity has been lost. The Prime Minister had an opportunity to provide leadership in giving an explanation of this issue to Australians, many of whom do not understand why they should apologise. I have had calls to my office today from well-meaning people who are confused about this issue-why should they say sorry? They have to understand and they have to be convinced. They would be convinced if there had been bipartisan support in this parliament for that proposition. It would have been a great day for us in this parliament. It would have been a defining moment, not only in the history of this parliament but in the history of this nation. We had the opportunity-we still have the opportunity in a sense, although it will not happen-for a bipartisan approach. If we had taken that opportunity, we could then have put this behind us and moved on towards the year 2001 when we will celebrate the lOath anniversary of our nationhood, with reconciliation advanced rather than retarded by the events of today. In the year 200 I, if we have not achieved reconciliation, then our celebrations, as I said yesterday, will be hollow, meaningless and hypocritical. An opportunity has passed us today and, as I said at the outset, it makes me very sad that that is the case. The government tactics in this matter really confuse and worry me. The fact is that because this motion by the Leader of the Opposition is supportable, and knowing that many of my former colleagues would, I suspect, want to support it were they given the opportunity to do so, this should be a conscience vote. If ever there were a matter that has come before this parliament that is a matter of deep conscience, this is such a matter. People on both sides of this House will want to apologise. For some reason, the government, in its tactical considerations, is going to deny members a consCience vote. They will be forced to vote against this motion. In doing so, many of them will also be forced, unfortunately, to vote against their conscience. I do not say that lightly because I know they all have a conscience and many would want to say today, in the context of this debate, 'I am sorry.' Yet we have an attempt by the government to supplant the Leader of the Opposition's very well designed motion with a meaningless self-congratulatory amendment. I will not support that amendment. It is supportable, but why should I? It is so hollow and meaningless. In fact, it is not a true amendment at all. It does not do anything to amend the opposition leader's motion. It is a totally different proposition altogether. It occurred to me, in terms of the standing orders, that it should not even have been accepted as an amendment, but I did not see much point in pursuing that particular issue.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: Mr Nehl}-You were very wise.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: NATIONAL SORRY DAY
text: Perhaps. I am not always so, but thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The amendment makes the point that it is all about money. This is where the government has this issue so wrong. Twice in the amendment we are called to note that the government is spending almost $1.9 billion on indigenous specific programs. We are reminded that the government is spending $63 million as a result of the Bringing them home report. In other words, we can spend our way out of this issue; we can solve this problem by spending more money. I would have thought the history of our handling of Aboriginal affairs in this place would have demonstrated time and again that throwing money at this problem will not solve it, as necessary as it is to improve the degree of disadvantage which our indigenous people suffer vis-a-vis all of us in this place who have had privileged upbringings. No amount of money, not billions of dollars, will substitute for the one word that we could have unanimously uttered in this place today, and that word is 'sorry'. If we had taken that opportunity, as a nation I think we would have achieved an enormous amount. As a parliament, we could have been proud of that achievement and the bipartisanship and leadership that would have been shown in doing that would have made us very proud to call ourselves Australians. Instead of that, I find myself, as I said at the outset, grieved and saddened by the approach that the government has taken on this issue. What is the problem? We have not heard from the ministers who have spoken what the problem is with saying sorry. Is it a legal problem? When the issue first came up, the proposition was put to us that somehow this would create a legal problem for the government. That now seems to have gone by the board and that argument is no longer put. If there was a legal argument, the Minister for Family Services is a lawyer and he did not put it. If there is a legal problem with saying sorry, then argue that way, but there is not. The reason for not saying sorry is a political one, and that is why it hurts. I think I understand the reason, having thought like that until maybe 12 or 18 months ago when I finally came to grips with the matter by spending time with some of my Aboriginal brothers and sisters and I came to understand what this was all about. There are a lot of people out there who do not understand, and the government seem to have the message that if they say sorry they will upset a lot of people, but that is where the issue of leadership comes in. Once we understand how important this issue is, how important this apology is to the process of reconciliation, that is when leadership comes in-to bring people with you on this issue. You cannot do anything else on this issue other than provide leadership and help people understand why it is important. And that, unfortunately, is what has been lacking. It was ironical that my friend the Minister for Family Services was called upon to speak in the debate on this motion, because the forced removal of children from their parents which we are talking about today has destroyed, and continues to destroy, thousands of Aboriginal families. The Minister for Family Services did not mention that. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I said, it is too late for the Prime Minister to apologise. Reconciliation, despite the government's embracing of it-and I believe that is genuine-will not be possible without an apology, and now, unfortunately, I believe that it will not be possible for a coalition government to deliver to this nation by the year 2001 the degree of reconciliation that we will need to have by then if we are to celebrate genuinely the lOOth anniversary of our nationhood. Unfortunately, I think that the government now has little credibility on this issue of reconciliation. It pains me to say that because I know it hurts a number of my former colleagues who I know very well and who I know today would be feeling very deeply on this issue and would be wanting to have the opportunity to say sorry. I do not entirely understand why the government has chosen the tactics, with its amendment, that it has. Mr Deputy Speaker, we need to move on. We could have put this matter behind us. Today was the opportunity to say sorry, to move on, to start looking forward, and to put all of this behind us, but we have missed that opportunity. As I said earlier, if the opportunity had been taken, there could have been a bipartisan approach. We have let Australia down. I think we have let ourselves as a parliament down by the way in which we have approached this issue. Finally, I do not intend to support the government's amendment to the motion. It is not unsupportable. It is self-congratulatory; it is largely factual. But on principle I will not support it because it is not in the spirit of what we are talking about. The opposition leader's motion is in the spirit of what this day is all about and what this week is all about. I will happily support that. The sad thing is that I do not think many of the government members coming into the chamber will even know what they are voting against. Perhaps it would be timely to remind them of what the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition actually states, because many of them will come in here and not realise that they are being forced, by virtue of the government's tactic on this matter, to vote against what I think is a perfectly reasonable proposition. I think the support of it would have furthered us as a nation, as individuals and as a parliament. Question put: That the amendment (Mr Warwick Smith's) be agreed to. The House divided. Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: -I move that the following words be added to the motion as amended: (5) records their concern for the policies that separated Aboriginal children from their parents, noting that this produced a basic denial of their human rights and caused great suffering; (6) and its Members apologise and record their deep regret for the pain and suffering endured by Aboriginal citizens; (7) and its Members apologise for the mistakes of the past in respect of Aboriginal citizens; and (8) records its gratitude to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, led by Sir Ronald Wilson, for their work in this area. It is not my intention to take any length of time on this because of the agreement we have on the debate, but it does seem to us that, given what we have heard from the other side, this proposition is a reconciling of the two motions and it is in the interests of reconciliation. Clearly we have signalled a preparedness to adopt as an addendum to our motion that which has been moved by the government. I think that when you have listened, as those of us who sat in this chamber did, to the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), you will note that they are prepared to say sorry and they find nothing wrong with the words. The member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford), who left the Liberal Party in part because of its NOES attitude on Aboriginals, has indicated succinctly that he can see nothing wrong in the two motions. Mr Reith- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: Yes, you have got the agreement andMr Reith-We had an agreement, and I think it is only reasonable that people adhere to an agreement which was fairly and honourably entered into.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: I cannot believe I heard that * denotes teller from the Leader of the House. Fairly and honourably! Legal! Come off it-the conspirator extraordinaire.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: -You will withdraw that.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: I withdraw it. The proposition that is involved here

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: NOES
text: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER Opposition members-He is out of his seat!

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: He is out of his seat. You are right.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: NOES
text: We want to bring the two motions together, and I believe that many members on that side of the House agree with that proposition. They have spoken to us privately about that, and this is what they want.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: Is the amendment seconded?

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: NOES
text: I second the amendment.

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: NOES
text: The government indicates that this amendment to our motion is not acceptable and will be rejected. Question put: That the words proposed to be added (Mr Crean's amendment) be so added. Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Speaker has received advice from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) that he has withdrawn the matter of public importance which he had submitted for discussion today. NA Selection Committee Report

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members business on Monday, 1 June 1998. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for the next sitting. The report read as followsReport relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 1 June 1998 Pursuant to sessional order 28D, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 1 June 1998. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list. COMMI'ITEE AND DELEGATION REPORTS Presentation and statements TREATIES-JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE: Report on Multilateral Agreement on Investment. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made-all statements to be made within a total time of 15 minutes. Speech time limitsEach Member-5 minutes. 2 LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS-STANDING COMMITTEE: Report on copyright, music and small business. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made-all statements to be made within a total time of 15 minutes. Speech time limitsEach Member-5 minutes. 3 PROCEDURE-STANDING COMMITTEE: Report on review of the House of Representatives committee system. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made-all statements to be made within the time remaining for committee and delegation reports. Speech time limitsFirst Member speaking-10 minutes. Other Members-5 minutes each. PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS Order of precedence Notices 1 Mr MCMullan to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the Corporations Law, in order to help protect the entitlements of employees. 2 Ms Kelly to move: That this House: (I) recognises that the former Labor Government created a child care system which was based on inequitable funding practices such as operational subsidies; (2) agrees that the Government's reform of the child care system provides for an equitable distribution of money between low and middle income families and the creation of an extra 83 000 places over the next four years; (3) notes and supports the Government's allocation of $4.9 billion to the child care system over the next four years; (4) calls on the Opposition to stop its campaign of misinformation to parents which threatens to do long-term damage to the child care sector as a whole; (5) notes that due to this Government's reforms low and middle income families are now better off than under the previous Government; and (6) condemns the former Labor Government for its management of the child care sector, creating a massive oversupply of centres in some areas and undersupply in others. Time allotted-remaining private Members' business time prior to 1.45 p.m. Speech time limitsEach Member-5 minutes. The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue Oil a future day. 3 Mr MCLeay to move: That this House calls on the Government to make closed captioning compulsory on all prime time programs and all news programs. (Notice given 23 March 1998.) Time allotted-30 minutes. Speech time limitsMover of motion-1 0 minutes. First Government Member speaking-10 minutes. Other Members-5 minutes each. The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. Orders of the day 1 PRIVATE HEALTH INSURANCE: Resumption of debate (from I December 1997) on the motion of Mr E. H. Cameron That this House: (1) acknowledges that Australia's health system is reliant on a successful private health insurance industry complementing the public health system; (2) notes with concern the neglect of the former Labor Government to stem the exodus from private health insurance between 1984 and 1996; (3) calls on the Australian Labor Party to agree to supporting incentives for private health insurance as part of its policy platform at its annual conference in 1998; (4) expresses its support for the incentives provided by the Federal Government for people to maintain private health insurance and for those who do not have it, to take it out; (5) calls on private health insurers to minimise any premium increases which may force more Australians to reconsider their membership; (6) welcomes any further policies which encourage people who can afford to take out private health insurance, to do so; and (7) calls on the Government to refer the issue of private health insurance and the Australian health system to the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs for further solutions to alleviate the decline in private health insurance caused by the policies former Labor Government. Time allotted-remaining private Members' business time. Speech time limitsEach Member-5 minutes. The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. Public Accounts and Audit Committee

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: COMMITTEES
text: La Trobe) (5.42 p.m.)On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit I present the committee's report entitled Draft estimates for the Austral1998-99 Ian National Audit Office for /998-99. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by Ieave-I table the The report on the draft budget estimates for the Australian National Audit Office for 1998-99 in accordance with provisions of section the Auditor-General Act 1997. The tabling this report is a historic occasion for committee which has a unique role in overNational sighting the process of budgetary approprito ation for the Australian National Audit Office. This measure is in itself a significant guarantee of the independence of the Auditor-General from executive government. In its report No. 346, Guarding the independence of the Auditor-General, tabled in October 1996, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended that it be given a statutory power to consider and report on draft budget estimates of the audit office as part of the then Auditor-General Bill. The committee argued that the proper of the Auditor-General and the ANAO was 'integral to the functional independence of the Auditor-General'. It also argued that it was the 'role of Parliament and not the Executive to take responsibility for ensuring that audit functions are adequately resourced'. Although under section 56 of the constitution it is indisputable that tt - office of the Auditor-General cannot be k,gally or cially independent from the executive in any absolute sense, it has been possible to insulate the Auditor-General's financing from executive influence to ensure that the audit office of the cannot be starved of funds. A process has been put in place whereby the draft budget estimates are considered by the JCPAA before the budget is handed down and the committee's report provided to the minister for finance to be tabled as soon as practical after the budget. This process allows the resourcing of audit functions to be made transparent to the parliament so that the executive is held to account for the level of Report resources appropriated to allow the Auditor General to fulfil the statutory functions of his office. With respect to the budget estimates for the financial year, the committee accepts that the budget appropriation figure of $53.703 million, as finally adjusted, is sufficient for the ANAO to carry out its functions. committee acknowledges the response of the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), who commented on the coopera53 of tive manner in which this unprecedented of process of parliamentary scrutiny was implethe mented by the JCPAA and the Australian Audit Office. I commend the report the House. I seek leave to move: That the House take note of the report. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr CHARLES
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That the House take note of the report, I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned.
