If these policy settings remained unchanged, the budget would have been broadly balanced this year in any case, without the unnecessary hardship caused to so many people by this government's attack on the well-being of average Australians. Labor's emphasis on growth leads to the creation of jobs and that directly affects the welfare and well-being of working people and the community in general. Labor's approach means more people in work and, for those in work, it means greater job security. The coalition's approach has opened up worrying gaps in Australian society. It has sought to divide the nation with its predatory race-based legislation and its shameful and illegal attack on waterfront workers. To sum up, Lance Morcom, my constituent from Birkenhead, got it right. The government has achieved its surplus on the backs of ordinary working Australians and the coalition has withdrawn financial assistance from those in our community who are most in need and called that windfall its budgetary surplus. On budget night, the Treasurer went looking for praise, but it was a cheap, harsh, sleight of hand which did not fool Lance Morcom and did not fool the majority of the electors in my electorate. I expect it will not fool many other Australians either.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: COMMITTEE
text: I welcome the opportunity to follow my colleague the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) in the appropriation debate. Mr Sawford-Again.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: COMMITTEE
text: Yes, again. The member for Port Adelaide, whose constituent Lance Morcom is unknown to me, provides me with just the springboard I want in this appropriation debate. Lance Morcom-as I said, unknown to me-allegedly said that, if the government had achieved a surplus, and indeed it has achieved a surplus of $2.7 billion, then it achieved it on the backs of ordinary Australians, if that is quoting the member for Port Adelaide correctly. Mr Sawford-Exactly.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: COMMITTEE
text: Thank you. If that is the case, then the member for Port Adelaide has, out of his own mouth, put the most powerful case for tax reform that has been put in this parliament, because he is indicating that, unfairly, we collected the money necessary to pay-off a budget deficit. Mrs Gallus-A budget deficit left by Labor.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: COMMITTEE
text: Absolutely, it was left by Labor. It was $10.3 billion. Mr Sawford-Talk about the current account deficit.

Speaker: Mr ANDREW
Title: COMMITTEE
text: The member for Port Adelaide, unable to resist one punch on the nose, wants another. So he said, 'What about the current account deficit?' He runs the nonsense they are so fond of opposite of suggesting that, in some strange way, the Australian economy is less able than ever before to face its current account deficit. This government never came in pretending that in one term it would rub out the problem of the current account. Never. We said we would get on with servicing the debt and we did. In fact, within one term, within two budgets, we have paid off that ALP debt. When it came to the current account, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) quite rightly said that, if you are dealing with a current account with an international debt that is running in excess of $200 billion, it will not disappear overnight. But what the member for Port Adelaide quite mischievously has failed to tell the House and failed to tell the people of this nation is that, in just two years, not only has this government paid off the debt we inherited from his team; in addition to that, we have placed this nation in a better position to service the current account than it has ever been before. When we came into government, our capacity to pay off the debt was soaking up something like 20 per cent of our gross domestic product. Tonight, it is soaking up something like 14 per cent because we have set all of the indicators in place so that we are in a better position, we are generating mor-, we have a greater gross domestic product and we are better able to pay off the debt and meet that current account obligation. If we stay on course, as we intend to do, in spite of the Asian crisis, that figure will fall by the tum of the century to 12 per cent-something you ought to applaud, not criticise. If, as we intend to do, we sell off the residual amount of Telstra, that debt will fall to one per centthe sort of figures not seen since the member for Port Adelaide was a boy in nappies. But have we had one measure of commendation from those opposite? No, of course not. Only the usual, convenient primary school teacher jibes often run by the member for Port Adelaide. Debate interrupted. NA

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Waterfront  p.m.)-I have previously referred to the malevolence of this government in respect of members of unions and their families. Tonight I re-emphasise that the government's debacle on the waterfront has been engineered and orchestrated from this building. The international scandal of Dubai, the international scandal of confrontation and dissension on the waterfront, was similarly engineered from this building. It was all done in association with ministers' offices in this building. But what is so anti-Australian and what is so malevolent has been the support given to Mr Chris Conigan's actions in contriving the bankruptcy of his own companies so as to enable him to avoid his companies' obligations towards his own companies' employees. His actions have been applauded, aided and abetted by this government. The proposal to provide financial support for enforced redundancy payments to sacked employees was rushed through the cabinet in this buildingwithout written submission but by verbal submission-months before the events of 7 April 1998. But for Mr Corrigan the process of bankrupting one's own companies to avoid liabilities to creditors, including employees' entitlements, was not new. He had earlier form. In June 1994, as chair of Australian Stevedores Ltd, he put forward a similar proposal in respect of the company's Darling Harbour operations. What he proposed on that occasion was to strip the assets out of the Darling Harbour activity, including any provisions that could be removed into another company, let the losses mount up to the value of the residual assets, and then bankrupt the activity so that there were no funds to meet any creditors, including workers' entitlements, using the corporate veil to isolate such liabilities to the bankrupt activity. Fortunately, that proposal that he advanced was rejected by the other shareholders of the company, but it went on to create a deadlock among the shareholders of the company. Earlier than that, we can look to the report of the inquiry into Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd and Petroleum Distributors Pty Ltd that was conducted from January 1981 to 25 May 1981 by J.W. von Doussa, QC., the inspector. I quote from paragraph 6.35: The evidence of Corrigan about his communications with IEL if correct, discloses a conflict of interest and a disregard for confidential information to an extent that I consider to be improbable. The report goes on to say: ... it seems that there was at no time any contractual relationship between Elders GM and BT (leaving aside the underwriting agreement made on 30th March 1981). Further on-and I am just taking selected parts because of time-the report says at 6.37: I consider the evidence shows that the story that IEL was BT'sthat is, BT Australia'sprincipal has been concocted after the event. It concludes at the end of that paragraph: In my opinion, the credit memorandum which the BT witnesses say was executed shortly after the date which it bears is also a sham. Honourable members can look further into that case and see more detail of that report at the time. But this government's debacle on the waterfront has cost this nation hundreds of millions of dollars-all based on the pretext of improving productivity. I have said on a number of occasions in this place and in the Main Committee that waterfront costs are a small proportion of the total costs of getting product to market. That is the major reason why shippers do not take much notice. But the Productivity Commission report on page 34 itself says: Waterfront charges make up a small proportion of importer's and exporter's freight bills ... Usually they are less than half of land-side charges and less than a quarter of the blue water freight charge. With respect to country dry cargo, the lift-on charges are 0.5 per cent of the total transport charge. In the case of city reefer charges, the lift-on charge or stevedoring charge for containers is 0.4 per cent of the total transport charges. These are readings from the government's own report about which they have bragged so much. But it exposes this whole charade, it exposes this disaster, as the contrivance it has been on the part of the government. Tourism

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: On 18 May, federal sport and tourism minister, the Hon. Andrew Thomson MP, visited my electorate of Paterson to meet with tourism operators and to announce formal details of the Commonwealth's promised $1 million infrastructure and marketing support package for the burgeoning Hunter tourism industry. The $1 million to the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation highlights the focus of the infrastructure funding towards building up the region as a legitimate stopover for international visitors and improving our growing reputation as a haven for quality and affordable eco-tourism pursuits. For instance, the $100,000 to the Nelson Bay Dolphin Interpretative Centre expands the federal government's support of the soon to be constructed visitor information and tourist centre to a figure now of $300,000. And a similar $100,000 allocation to the Shortland Wetlands Centre is proof that eco-tourism is now very much the financial lifeblood of the Hunter tourism industry. An investment of $250,000 will be made in the Hunter Wine Interpretive Centre planned for construction at Cessnock, $50,000 will be allocated to improve visitor information signage to better promote our region's tourist attractions, and a collective $160,000 initiative to bolster international and domestic marketing is a strategic pointer that the local tourism industry, whilst now generating close to $1 billion annually for the Hunter economy, has to become more visitor friendly. Tourism in the Hunter is not only well on the way to becoming one of our region's largest industry sectors; in terms of employment, one in nine of all new jobs created in our region now come directly under the tourism umbrella. It was with great pleasure that I joined the minister and Great Lakes Mayor, John Chadban, in officially opening the longawaited Bulahdelah Tourism and Visitors Information Centre. The opening of the Great Lakes Tourism Centre at Bulahdelah in effect completes the network of promotional centres in areas like Pacific Palms, Dungog, Hawks Nest, Nelson Bay and Maitland that now exist right around the Hunter, aiming to facilitate further exciting growth in tourist numbers and spending. These centres have correlated a strong upturn in recorded growth in tourism spending within each community as holiday makers and passing travellers become successfully armed with the critical information of what to see and do and where to explore. With the majestic waterways of Port Stephens, the Barrington wilderness area, our world famous wineries and the unique physical environment, the Hunter has all the hallmarks to rival Cairns and the Top End as a must see regional destination for the some four million international visitors that annually travel to Australia. So, Mr Speaker, you can understood why I was disappointed and a little dismayed to be alerted to comments made by the shadow tourism minister, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), in the Illawarra Mercury last Wednesday, attributing the Hunter tourism industry to nothing more than possessing a bunch of wineries for prospective travellers.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: You won't have to worry about that for much longer.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The member for Denison was warned earlier today. I suggest he remain silent.

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The shadow minister, in comparing the respective potential of the Hunter, Blue Mountains and Wollongong tourism industries, assessed the exciting developments in the Hunter tourism sector in the following light. He said: Our colleagues in the Hunter seem to be able to get their act together a little better and all they've got is the wine industry and not much else. I have come to ask the question: how out of touch is Mr Martin when it comes to the Hunter tourism industry? What makes the shadow minister's foolish and silly remark all the more stunning is that Mr Martin was actually in the Hunter region on the day of the release to speak on-guess what? The potential of Hunter tourism. Yet Mr Martin flippantly dismisses and ignores the real growth and genuine dynamism that is occurring right across the Hunter on the tourism front, even when it is happening right under his own nose. When Stephen Martin visited Port Stephens last week, did he stop to think that over 700,000 visitors travelled to the water wonderland in the past year alone?

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I trust the member for Denison has a point of order that is relevant.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I do, Mr Speaker. I would ask the member to refer to the member for Cunningham by his correct title.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member will resume his seat.

Speaker: Mr BOB BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: When the member contested. for Cunningham visited Port Stephens last week, did he stop to think that 700,000 visitors travelled to the water wonderland in the past year alone? Further, why would he dismiss out of hand the nationally acclaimed Morpeth Jazz Festival, which attracted thoua sands of visitors to Maitland's tourism jewel over the weekend? The bottom line is that the member for Cunningham is a disgrace. I ca1l on all memstate election. bers in the Hunter, including the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), who sits on his hands at all times, to do something about and not suffer the embarrassment of having a shadow minister for tourism who does nothing for the Hunter. Speaker: Mr TONY SMITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think it is necessary to put a number of things on the record in relation to the background to my resigning from the Liberal Party and becoming the eighth Independent in this parliament. The first thing at an FEC meeting of the Liberal Party some four weeks ago I moved a motion which was supported by the FEC meeting to bring ahead the preselection for the seat of Dickson. It is important to bear that in mind, given what the boffins are now saying. I wanted that preselection brought forward so that it could be I believe I would have won preselection for the seat of Dickson. If there is anything more clear to demonstrate the fact that I wanted it brought on, it is the motion that I moved and letter that was sent. I have a letter in my possession which was sent by NIr Goebel, the State Director of the Liberal Party-that is, Greg Goebel-in which he said that the preselection would be delayed until after the The moment I resigned today, the preselecthis tion is on this Sunday. With that in mind, perhaps I am a little naive, but I thought that when you had correspondence with someone you did not reveal it unless you asked for that person's consent. I think that is a very naive view to have. I suppose as a lawyer you do not reveal correspondence unless you say, do you mind if I send a copy of that?' But, in my naivety, I did not think that that But it did happen in the case of a letter I sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). I want to read that letter because this is my letter of resignation. It states: As of today I hereby resign my membership of the Parliamentary Liberal Party. My decision has been reached after long hours of reflection and discuswith those close to me. My experience of the system has led me to the irresistible concluthat it is impossible to properly represent the interests of my constituents as a member of the centre now parliamentary party. Just as with native title, child support and now a proposed GST, my input as a representative of the constituents of Dickson is ignored as decisions have already been made. You expect me to jump and rubber stamp them as directed. It is intolerable. This is in the context of having lost confidence in you as leader of the parliamentary party. You seem unconcerned about the real people out there whose views you find an irritation. The interests of my constituents come first and foremost and nothing will deter me from doing my duty to them. to say is that Yours sincerely Tony Smith Bearing in mind the fact of my preselection, this is the response. It states: Dear Tony I have your letter of resignation. The reasons given for your resignation lack conviction. That is the first point-'lack conviction'. I moved in this House from that position over there last week an amendment to government legislation. How could that demonstrate more conviction to what I believed in? That was my reason. One of my reasons was child support. I did not vote on native title. How could you demonstrate more conviction for what you believe in by walking out of the House and not voting? Let me have enough of that sort of humbug. The letter continues: They are not borne out by the facts. Well, that remains to be seen. It continues: The criticism you have made. I reject. Fair enough. I have no problem with that. After all, I did not attack the Prime Minister in any personal way in my letter. This is a political letter. But here is the beauty: I think that most people know the real reason you have resigned. Isn't that nice! Doesn't that betray something about Mr Howard that perhaps the people of Australia have not seen before? That is the question I ask. What does he mean? Does he mean my preselection or does he mean my personal life? Is that what he is saying? Is that what he is really saying? Well, why doesn'the say it?

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Hindmarsh) (10.45 p.m.)Today I would like to mention something that happened to me at the weekend, and that was a visit to one of my local churches, the Church of the Good Shepherd in Plympton. It was an invitation to have a look at some houses that they had just built for lower income families. I went along expecting to see the normal couple of houses that are usually built in this situation and, indeed, that was so. They were very attractive houses that were built on church land-<>n disused basketball courts. But what was absolutely fascinating about these houses is that they had been built with the environment in mind and with the retention of water for landscaping. I will read to the House from the booklet that I was presented with at the church service of dedica. tion. I was so intrigued by the whole concept that, while I was there, I missed out on my following appointment that Sunday. I have yet to give my letter of apology to the second appointment. You have the church and then behind the church is vacant land. These houses have been built on the side, and more will be built behind the church. The brochure states: Roof runoff from buildings at the church site passes to a gravel-filled trench beneath a gardenllawn area, formerly a disused basketball court. The collected water evaporates through the gravel, providing moisture directly to the roots of the shrubs and grass above. So you are not watering from the top, you are using evaporation to keep your grass and shrubs alive. It goes on: The landscaped area requires minimal, if any, supplementary irrigation. storm runoff from the roofs is diverted by a network of pipes to storage in the gravel-filled trench; in periods between storms, vapor generated form moist gravelMr Leo MCLeay-Moist gravel.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I am reading from this and I think they mean 'from moist gravel'enters the soil and vegetation root mass above. . .

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I suggest to the members across the table who find this funny that they might learn something from this project and might be able to suggest this type of thing in their own neighbourhoods, because it is an excellent project. To laugh at it portrays something about the members across the floor.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The member for Watson will remain silent. I would suggest that the member for Hindmarsh continue her remarks.

Speaker: Mrs GALLUS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The brochure goes on: this "passive" system of irrigation is more efficient than conventional watering and, normally, requires little, if any, mains water application. in large storms, short-term ponding occurs ... this water then feeds slowly to the underground gravel layer; in very large storms, runoff exceeding the pond capacity ... passes to the street drainage system; the overall scheme reduces downstream flooding, uses storm runoff to provide catchment "greening" and places little to no demand on mains water supply. If this type of development were used in all the suburbs, then we would have less problems with our water. It is especially relevant to South Australia and to the city of Adelaide, with South Australia being the driest state in the driest continent and Adelaide being the head city in South Australia. In conclusion, I make mention of the people who participated in the dedication service and who bear responsibility for this project: Rev. Barry Davis, the parish priest who bears the greatest responsibility; church elders Mr Harold Bates-Brownsword and Mr Jack Stirling; the architect, Rodney Barrington; the builder, Mr John Twelftree; and Mr John Argue, Associate Professor of Water Engineering, University of South Australia. I congratulate the city of West Torrens and the state government for their contributions and I also mention the Most Rev. Ian George, the Archbishop of Adelaide, who fully supported the project from beginning to end. It is a most excellent project, and I would commend it to the sneering members of the bpposition across the table. Member for Paterson

Speaker: Mr ALLAN MORRIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I will continue but I will also ask you, after tonight, to look at mem- tomorrow's Hansard and look at the remarks of the member for Paterson and then reflect on your ruling on me. The member for Paterson came into office when the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation a week before had received $10 million. He is here boasting about $1 million three years later. The organisation has been gutted since he has been in office. The same member is trying to laud the contribution of this government to the electorate and to the Hunter itself. The wharf that he goes game fishing off, which cost $4 million, was all contributed by the Labor government. That is one project alone that is four times the value than the of what he is boasting about. The more interesting point is that, just the week before last, the budget papers showed that the $6 million the member for Paterson announced last year-to be spent at Williamtown airport-was not spent. So what does he do? He announces it again this year. He recycles it. Great environmentalist-he recycles $6 million from last year's budget which was not spent-not a word said-and he spends it again next year. Terrific! He is great at recycling. Mr Speaker, I think you will find the people of Paterson will recycle him back to the Central Coast, where he came from. He was a blow-in from the Central Coast and he will be recycled back there. (Time expired) Warburton Hospital

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: MCEwen) (10.54 p.m.)The town of Warburton in the Upper Yarra region of my electorate has had a close association with the Seventh Day Adventist Church for over 75 years. Gradually over those decades the church has extended its presence by establishingMr Leo MCLeay-On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I want the member for Paterson now to withdraw two allegations. Earlier, when the member for Newcastle was addressing

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member will resume his place. The honourable member for Paterson will withdraw the allegations made-he will rise in his place and withdraw the remarks unconditionally. Mr Bob Baldwin-Which allegation was that, Mr Speaker?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The honourable member will withdraw his imputation unconditionally. Mr Bob Baldwin-I withdraw.

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Speaker. After all of these antics I would like to get back to talking about some serious issues in my electorate. The Seventh Day Adventist Church in Warburton has established the Sanitarium Weetbix factory, Signs Publishing Company, an aged care facility, a hospital, a school, a church and has provided accommodation to numerous families. This has represented not just a huge financial investment, but an enormous social and spiritual commitment to Warburton. Importantly, it has provided secure employment to hundreds of local people. The church has in fact become synonymous with the name Warburton. Just over 12 months ago, Sanitarium, one of the companies owned by the church, made a commercial decision to close its Weetbix factory and ended not just a 75-year history, but also the working careers of over 80 employees. The effect on the town of Warburton of that decision, while still being by the community, was not as devastating as many feared because locals were determined that the town would survive by promoting its natural assets. Just as this small town was beginning to pick itself up, it was dealt another body blow. The church announced that it proposed to sell both the hospital and the health care centre, putting the jobs of 140 people immediately at risk, but also putting a huge question mark over the future viability of the town. Many locals contacted me from various different sections of the community. Many were distraught at the news. I actually said that they had two choices. They could simply wait and see what happened and who bought the facilities; or they could, as a community, pull together and convince the church that at the very least they should allow the recent restructuring of the hospital time to take effect and, preferably, to convince the owners that it was not in the best interests of either the church or the local community to sell the complex. We chose the latter course of action. Together with Steve Brown, a local businessman, Gary Hendrick and Monica Keane from the Upper Yarra business association, I organised a public meeting at the hospital. I must also give credit to Bob Manners, the CEO of the hospital, and his staff for the tremendous support they gave us and for allowing us to hold the meeting at the hospital. I encouraged those present at the meeting by telling them that, if the community were to save the hospital, then the community had to pull together and work in partnership. It gives me enormous pride and pleasure to be able to tell this House that out of that meeting came support from SDA, non-church members, management and staff of the hospital and health care centre, business people, community groups and the local mediapeople from all walks of life and all political persuasions. From that fantastic support base we formed a strategy committee consisting of Steve Brown, Gary Hendrick, June Ivey, Jan Cameron, Monica Keane, Keith Johanson, Maurie MCQuade, Graham Sweet and yours truly. We organised a petition and within one felt week we managed to collect just over 2,000 signatures. My office faxed those to a conference that was being held on Friday, Saturday and Sunday of last weekend. Pastor Bob Manners, in his capacity as CEO of the hospital, actually asked the conference to withdraw the facilities from sale. And I am pleased to report that, as a result of our action and the pressure that we managed to bring to bear, the church leaders have actually withdrawn those properties from sale. I want to place on record my thanks to all of those members of the community who acted so spontaneously. I know that the commitment they brought to this issue and the pressure they applied to the hospital leaders is going to stand the community in good stead. I intend working with those community members and, in tum, bringing pressure to bear on government to provide public beds to assist in the future viability of that hospital.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being almost 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. House adjourned at 11.00 p.m. NA The following notices were given: Mr Williams to present a Bill for an Act to provide for financial assistance in connection with the implementation of the national firearms program, and for related purposes. Mr Somlyay to move: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal for work in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 25 May 1998, namely: Erection of signage on and around the headquarters of the National Archives of Australia at East Block. NA The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 26 May 1998: Australian Bureau of Statistics Act-Australian Bureau of Statistics-Proposals 1998 Nos. 9, 10, 11. Customs Act-Instrument of approval 1998 No.5. The following answers to questions were circulated: (Question No. 2610) I Mr MCClelland asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: Is the Minister able to say which (a) countries and (b) international organisations recognise Taiwan as the Republic of China. Mr Downer-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: With regard to (a), as of 1 May 1998, Taiwan had diplomatic relations with 27 countries. At that date, all 27 countries listed below recognised Taiwan as the "Republic of China": Republic of Malawi; Kingdom of Swaziland; Republic of Senegal; Burkina Faso; The Republic of Gambia; The Republic of Liberia; Sao Tome and Principe; The Republic of Chad; The Holy See; Belize; The Republic of Costa Rica; The Republic of EI Salvador; The Republic of Guatemala; The Republic of Honduras; The Republic of Nicaragua; The Republic of Panama; The Republic of Paraguay; Dominican Republic; Commonwealth of Dominica; Grenada; Republic of Haiti; Saint ChristopherNevis; St. Vincent and the Grenadines; The Republic of Nauru; Kingdom of Tonga; Tuvalu; Solomon Islands. With regard to (b), since 1971, when the People's Republic of China (PRC) joined the United Nations, Taiwan has not had membership of any UN bodies under any name. According to Appendix 3-Table 3 of the 199798 Yearbook of International Organizations, Vol 2, Taiwan was in 1997 a member of 908 non-governmental international organisations and 11 intergovernmental. The yearbook identified those latter organisations as: Afro-Asian Rural Reconstruction Organisation; Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC); Asian Productivity Organisation; International Cotton Advisory Committee; International Institute of Refrigeration; International Office of Epizootics; International Seeds Testing Association (*status pending); International Sericultural Commission; Pacific Basin Economic Council; Southern Africa NA Taiwan Regional Tourism Council; World Trade Organisation (*application pending). Taiwan now participates in intergovernmental and non-governmental international organisations under several different names. These include "Taiwan", "Taiwan, China", "Taiwan-China", "Taiwan (China)", and "Taiwan, Republic of China". Taiwan participates in APEC and the Olympic Games under the name "Chinese Taipei". Taiwan has applied for WTO membership under the name, "Customs Territory of Taiwan, P' enghu, Kinmen, and Matsu". In addition, Taiwan participates in some international conferences and meetings as "China (Taipei)", "China-Taipei" or "Taipei, China". Higher Education: Studies (Question No. 2627) Mr ·Latham asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) What are the total equivalent full-time student units by discipline category for (a) commencing students and (b) all students for each higher education institution for each year from 1996 to 2000 undertaking (i) higher degree research, (ii) higher degree coursework, (iii) other postgraduate, (iv) undergraduate and (v) enabling studies. Dr Kemp-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Information on enrolments for 1996 and 1997 is at Attachment A. The information at attachment A includes data on commencing students for 1997 only. Comparable information for commencing equivalent full-time students for 1996 and 1997 is unavailable because of a change in reporting requirements. I am not prepared to make available the information requested for the period 1998 to 2000 since this information can only be obtained from universities' profiles documentation, which is confidential. Release of individual universities' planning projections by discipline category may be detrimental to the interests of the institutions concerned. This approach is consistent with the practice of all previous Ministers with respect to this data. Trade: Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry Grants (Question Nos 2635 and 2636) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Has the Minister or the Minister's Department provided grants to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACC!) or bodies related to the ACCI since 2 March 1996; if so, in each case, (i) what was the nature of the grant; and (ii) for what purposes was it provided; and what total sum was provided. (2) To what boards, committees or other bodies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility have (a) Mr Mark Patterson, the chief executive of ACCI, or (b) other officers or staff of ACC] been appointed since 2 March 1996. (3) What sums has the Commonwealth paid in sitting fees, board fees, travel costs and related expenses with respect to each appointment referred to in part (2). - Mr Downer-As indicated above the honourable member has asked identical questions of both ministers. The following answer is provided on behalf of both ministers: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (1) No grants have been provided to ACCI by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. (2) (a) Nil. (b) According to the 1997 Annual Report of the ACCI, Mr Harold Clough was a member of the Board of the ACCI until the end of 1997. Mr Clough was appointed to the Advisory Panel for the White Paper on Australia's Foreign and Trade Policy in August 1996. The work of the Advisory Higher Degree Highere Degree Other Post- UnderResearch Course-work graduate graduate Enabling Total EFrSU EFrSU EFrSU EFrSU EFrSU EFrSU 0 0 0 9 0 9 132 5 34 547 0 718 0 0 0 70 0 70 5 0 5 42 0 52 73 2 12 249 0 336 0 0 0 4 15 19 0 0 0 0 0 0 33 8 8 218 0 267 0 0 I 52 0 53 0 0 0 3 0 3 857 93 300 4.952 28 6.230 Panel ceased with pUblication of the White Paper in August 1997. (3) According to our records, Mr Clough received a total of $4969 for his attendance at three meetings of the White Paper Advisory Panel. This covered airfares from Perth and travelling allowance of $200 per overnight stay. Austrade (1) No grants have been provided to ACCI by Austrade. (a) Nil. (b) An ACCI representative has been a member of the Export Access Management Committee from inception of the Export Access program in October 1991. (3) Nil. AusAID (1) (a) (i) A grant was approved as part of the ASEAN Australian Economic Cooperation Program (AAECP) Linkages Stream in February 1997 by the Joint Linkages Stream Appraisal Panel (JLSAP) in Jakarta. The Linkages Stream program funds smallscale short duration activities that aim to promote economic cooperation between ASEAN and Australia by establishing cooperative and joint activities involving the private, research, academic and government sectors in ASEAN and Australia. Linkages Stream activities contribute towards enhanced trade and investment links between ASEAN and Australia as well as contribute to sustainable development and economic growth in ASEAN. AusAID contributions for activities range from a minimum of $A25,OOO and will generally not exceed $A250,OOO. Funds for successful proposals will be provided up to a maximum of 60% of total eligible projcct costs and will be provided in arrears. (ii) The approved proposal involved the following three main objectives: To develop commercial opportunities between Small Medium Enterprises (SME) in Australia and in regional areas in ASEAN through an exchange of missions by business people with targeted business interests with particular regard to training and technology transfer opportunities; To assess and report on commercial prospects for Australian SME in the regional areas nominated (cities in Indonesia and Vietnam) to form the basis for development of a regional SME business linkages strategy with these areas; and To strengthen and expand the trade facilitation network between State and regional Chambers of Commerce and Industry in Australia and counterpart business associations in ASEAN through mutually beneficial commercial exchange. (b) AusAID agreed to fund the proposal to the value of $174,042 (60% of agreed 'eligible activity costs'). The project is sehedulcd for completion 31 May 1998. AusAlD signed an agreement under the AAECP Linkages Stream program in July 1997 with the Victorian Employer's Chamber of Commerce and Industry (VECCI). The project has since attracted one progress payment of $77,456 on 16 March 1998. (2) Nil. (3) Nil. Superannuation Benefits: Emigrants (Question No. 2681) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1998: (1) Under the new regulations relating to the early release of superannuation benefits when a person departs permanently from Australia, is a person required to lodge a new notice of intention if the person had previously lodged a notice of intention by 30 June 1997 under the regulations issued on 25 June 1997. (2) What will be the position of persons who had not lodged a notice of intention by 30 June 1997 under the regulations issued on 25 June 1997 but who departed permanently from Australia before his press release on changes to the arrangements for early release of superannuation benefits was issued on 17 November 1997. (3) What information will the Government provide to persons who had lodged a notice of intention on the basis of the regulations issued on 25 June 1997 which no longer has effect if they do not depart permanently from Australia before 1 July 1998. Mr Costello-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No. (2) These persons will be able to access their superannuation benefits on the ground of permanent departure from Australia provided a written request for release of their benefit is made to the trustee before 1 July 1998. (3) The regulations issued on 25 June 1997 amending the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (Statutory Rules No. 153 of 1997) included a transitional provision which allows persons who have lodged a written request with their fund trustees prior to I July 1997 to have their benefits released on the ground of permanent departure after 1 July 1997. Under the subsequent regulations foreshadowed in the Assistant Treasurer's press release of 17 November 1997 (Statutory Rules No. 343 of 1997), these transitional arrangements are maintained. Therefore, members of superannuation funds and approved deposit funds who lodged notices of intention prior to 1 July 1997 are not necessarily required to depart from Australia by 1 July 1998 and their notices of intention do not cease to have effect on that date. It should be noted however, that the new rules relating to the early release of superannuation benefits have been publicised generally through the Assistant Treasurer's press release of 17 November 1997, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission's Trustee newsletters, as well as numerous industry publications. Overseas Australian Missions (Question No. 2707) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 1998: (1) Have current employees at overseas Australian Government missions ever been found guilty of (a) sexual harassment or (b) sexual assault; if so, is he able to (i) identify the (A) employees, (B) mission at which each is employed, (C) exact nature of the offence committed by each, (D) year the offence was committed and (E) year each began employment at the mission and (ii) explain why the employees are considered to be of fit and proper character to represent Australia by working at an overseas mission; if not, why not. (2) Before a person is employed at an overseas Australian Government mission, is a check conducted on whether the person was ever found guilty of a criminal act; if not, why not. Mr Downer-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) I have been advised by the agencies covered by the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio-i.e. the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Agency for International Development and the Australian Trade Commission-that a check of the relevant disciplinary files held by these agencies has not revealed any current employees of those agencies at overseas Australian Government missions as having been found guilty of sexual harassment or sexual assault. If the Honourable member is aware of any employee who has been found guilty of such offences and she believes appropriate follow-up action has not been taken, I urge her to provide all relevant information to either myself, the relevant agency within my portfolio or the Australian Federal Police. I can assure the Honourable Member that if she were to bring any such information to my attention it would be investigated promptly and thoroughly. (2) r have been advised by the above agencies that such checks are conducted. Natural Heritage Trust: Funding (Question No. 2708) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 3 March 1998: (l) How many project applications for funding under the first phase of the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust did the Minister receive. (2) How many applications were successful. (3) What criteria were used to select the successful applications. (4) Will the Minister list the project applications, including proposals put forward by city councils or other interested organisations, from the electoral divisions of (a) Prospect, (b) Chifley, (c) Fowler, (d) Reid, (e) Blaxland, (f) Macarthur, (g) Werriwa, (h) Parramatta, (i) Lindsay, G) Greenway, (k) Mitchell and (1) Macquarie indicating which were successful and what sum was allocated in each case; if not, why not. (5) Did representatives from (a) Fairfield City Councilor (b) Holroyd City Council have discussions with representatives of the Minister's Department or office about obtaining funding under the first phase; if so, (i) when did the discussions take place, (ii) who was present and (iii) what environmental projects were put forward as worthy of receiving funding. (6) Did the Minister's Department allocate funding for environmental projects for which it received no application; if so, (a) which projects, (b) what sum was allocated in each case and (c) how were they selected. (7) Did the Cooma Monaro Shire Council receive a grant of $350 000 under the first phase specifically for flood management; if so, (a) will the Minister provide specific details of how the funding will be used, (b) is it a fact that the Council did not apply for the funding; if so, why was the funding allocated and (c) did the Council apply to the Minister for money from the Trust; if so, what are the details. (8) Did the Government discontinue the Urban Flood Mitigation Program which guaranteed funding to local government bodies to carry out necessary flood management work. (9) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to Fairfield City Council's requirement for $33 million over the next 15 years to complete the necessary construction it has identified in its approved floodplain management program. (10) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to 1998 being the tenth anniversary of the last major flood in the Fairfield City Council area which resulted in (a) the rescue of 550 persons by the Applications State Emergency Service, (b) the flooding above floor level of approximately 700 dwellings and more than 30 factories with some houses inundated to depths exceeding two metres and (c) millions of dollars worth of damage. (11) Was funding under the first phase of the Natural Heritage Trust allocated to Fairfield City Council for nood management; if not, why not. Mr Anderson-The Minister for the Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) For 1997-98, the first full year of the Natural Heritage Trust, I received 1027 applications for funding which were recommended by the State Assessment Panels through the One-Stop-Shop coordinated by the Statefferritory Governments. I understand the Minister for Primary [ndustries and Energy received a further 2143 applications. In total, 3170 applications were received from States and Territories through the One-Stop-Shop process. (2) A total of 2462 projects were approved in the first round of approvals for 1997-98. (3) The criteria used were set out in the publication Natural Heritage Trust Guide to Community Group Applications 1997-98. (4) The attached table lists all applications received from the State Assessment Panels from the specified electoral divisions, so far as I have been able to determine. (5) Officers of my Department and staff in my office are not aware of any such discussions. They have been unable to find any record of such discussions. (6) No. (7) A proposal for a grant of $350,000 to the Cooma Monaro Shire Council does not fall within my portfolio responsibilities. I would suggest that the honourable member directs part (7) of her question to my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Joint Committee on $0 land Conservation Necropolis Trustees Habitat Upper Cooks River Rookwood Campbelltown City $17,000 Bush Region Council Radio Communications (Question No. 2714) Mr Kerr asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 March 1998: Is it a fact that yachts and fishing vessels, in full survey with approved radio equipment, voyaging in southern and western Tasmanian waters are unable to communicate with Melbourne Radio contrary to assurances provided before Hobart Radio was closed; if so why. . Mr Warwick Smith-The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: Telstra and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) have advised the following: The International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea (the SOLAS Convention) requires that member countries provide communication services for vessels which operate under that Convention. In broad terms, such vessels are those in excess of 300 Gross Registered Tons. In fulfilling Australia's obligations under the SOLAS Convention, AMSA provides a network of six Coast Radio Stations for safety and distress communications with vessels at sea. These stations are located at Melbourne, Perth, Darwin, Townsville, Brisbane and Sydney and are managed and operated by Telstra under contractual arrangements with AMSA. A station at Hobart, which previously had been part of the Coast Radio, Station network, was closed in 1992. Telstra has also provided additional maritime communications services, in its own right, separately from its contract with AMSA. Under the provisions of the SOLAS Convention, traditional methods of maritime communications are being replaced through the Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS). The GMDSS is required to be fully implemented by 1999. Until that time, the network of Coast Radio Stations may be suitable to the needs of Staterrerritory-registered vessels including yachts and fishing vessels, providing they are equipped with suitable radio equipment. Staterrerritory-registered vessels fall outside the scope of the SOLAS Convention and responsibility for providing their communications service falls to State and Territory governments. This long-standing arrangement was confirmed by Commonwealth and Staterrerritory Ministers for Transport at the Australian Transport Advisory Council in 1992 when it was accepted by the Council that: (a) the Australian Coast Radio Network is established primarily for SOLAS vessels, (b) if non-SOLAS vessels wish to use the network, they must fit all Medium Frequency and High Frequency radiotelephone distress channels (from 2 to I 6 MHz) to guarantee reliable access; and (c) if State governments are not satisfied with the service provided by the network they are free to establish their own maritime communications infrastructure. Vessels operating in Tasmanian waters are able to communicate effectively with the network of Coast Radio Stations, providing they are fitted with appropriate radio equipment. Such equipment may be in excess of that required by State government regulations. A key element of the design in the Coast Radio Network is that any station in the network, not necessarily that which is geographically closest, can respond to an emergency call. Calls from ships located in Tasmanian waters will not necessarily be responded to by the station at Melbourne but can be received and acted upon by anyone of the stations in the network, provided that an appropriate frequency has been selected. AMSA and Telstra are confident that the network of Coast Radio Stations continues to provide an efficient and effective service to vessels in Tasmanian waters, provided those vessels are fitted with the appropriate equipment. AMSA has advised that through the National Maritime Safety Committee, State and Territory governments are considering the communication needs of non-SOLAS vessels, following the completion of the GMDSS in 1999. Robinson, Mr Floyd (Question No. 2735) Mr Campbell asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 March 1998: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Western Times of 18 December 1997 that Mr Floyd Robinson was fined for possession and supply of a dangerous drug, drink driving and other driving offences. (2) Is it a fact that a car owned by the Department of Finance and Administration and leased to Mr Robinson's father, a deputy chairman of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, was used as a base to sell drugs; if so, what action has he or his Department taken. Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) Any action in this matter is for the consideration of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Protocol to the Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (Question No. 2791) Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1998: (1) Does his Department have to consult with State and Territory governments and agencies in deciding whether Australia is to become a party to the Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague, 1954); if so, with which State and Territory governments and agencies has his Department consulted and on what dates, in what form and with what outcomes. (2) Which Parties to the Convention on the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of $75,396.00 $23,072.00 $1,287.00 Armed Conflict (The Hague, 1954) are not parties to the Protocol. Mr Downer-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) No decision has been made as to whether Australia is to become party to the Protocol to the Hague Convention. The Department of Communications and the Arts, the Department of Defence, the - ttorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade will continue to review this issue at the inter-agency level. In signifi- making such a decision, the Commonwealth Department with prime responsibility for Australia's potential ratification of the Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (the Hague, 1954) must consult with State and Territory governments before Australia could ratify the Protocol, pursuant to the treaty-making process. To date, no such consultations have occurred. (2) The following countries are a Party to the Convention on the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (the Hague, 1954), but are not Parties to the Protocol: Argentina; Australia; Cote d'Ivoire; Croatia; Dominican Republic; Estonia; Kyrgyzstan; Mongolia; Oman; Panama; Qatar; Saudi Arabia; Sudan; Tanzania; Uzbekistan. Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (Question No. 2796) Mr Barry Jones asked the Attorney General, upon notice, on 25 March 1998: (1) Does his Department cooperate with other Commonwealth departments in deciding whether Australia is to become a party to the Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague 1954). (2) Does his Department have to consult with State and Territory governments and agencies in deciding whether Australia is to become a party to the protocol; if so, with which State and Territory governments and agencies has his Department consulted and on what dates, in what form and with what outcomes. Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Yes. A number of Departments have an interest in whether Australia should become a party to the Protocol for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict (The Hague 1954), including: the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Defence, the Department of Communications and the Arts and the Attorney-General's Department. Consideration of that matter is dependent on priorities and the availability of resources. (2) Before Australia ratifies any treaty or related instrument, consultation with State and Territory governments will take place in accordance with treaty processes. No such consultations have occurred to date in relation to the protocol. (2) Is it a fact that some public telephones retain a coin slot but will not pennit calls to be made after a coin is inserted and do not provide a coin return mechanism resulting in potential users losing their coins; if so, why is a coin slot retained. (3) What consideration has been given to public telephone users who have small change but no smart card. (4) What options are available to users referred to in part (3) in cases of emergency. (5) Does Telstra provide a warning notice on public telephone booths not accepting coins; if not, why not. (6) Is it a fact that advice that the telephone will not accept coins appears on a small electronic display panel only after coins are inserted; if so, why. (7) What sum has Telstra collected because persons have inserted coins into coin slots without success. (8) How does Telstra use the sum referred to in part (7), Mr Warwick Smith-The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) As at 31 March 1998, approximately 24,000 of the 35,000 public payphones operated by Telstra have been converted to joint smart card/coin usage, with over 30,000 expected to be converted by mid1998. (2) Except for a small number of special-purpose payphones designed to meet the requirements of special groups, for example corrective institutions and some secondary and tertiary institutions, and specifically manufactured without a coin slot, all of the new payphones will accept every Australian coin and all have a coin return mechanism. However, payphones are subject to vandalism which can render them inoperable for coin operation. Once the coin mechanism is vandalised, the new payphones will normally operate using a Smart Card. If the new payphone detects that both the coin and card mechanisms are damaged, the payphone places itself in the "Free Local Call" mode. Telstra's new payphones automatically report themselves out of order, enabling Telstra to readily respond to faults. In some high vandalism prone areas, Telstra has converted new phones, on a temporary basis, to card-only operation to ensure that there is a functional payphone available. In these cases, the coin chute is blocked off, ensuring coins cannot be inserted. (3) See answer to (2) above. Other cashless calling options available to users of public payphones include Telstra's Homelink Service, the Phoneaway prepaid calling card, Freecall 1800 calls and Automatic and Operated Assisted Reverse Charge calls. (4) The "000" emergency service is available without the use of cards or coin. In the event of "emergency" situations which do not involve police, fire or ambulance the options set out in (3) above are available. (5) Except for a small number of payphones modified for special "card only" purposes (and manufactured without a coin slot), all new payphones are intended to accept every Australian coin. When new payphones are temporarily modified to avoid vandalism as mentioned in (3) above, Telstra blocks off the coin entry slot. Telstra is in the process of producing a sticker to place on the payphone advising that coins are not accepted. (6) No. If damage to the coin mechanism has been detected, the electronic screen lights up when the handset is lifted and clearly displays the message "INSERT CARD" in bold 20 point type. Because the screen is normally dark, the user's attention is immediately drawn to the lit message. Depending on where the coin blockage has occurred, the display may permanently display the message "LIMITED SERVICE-CARD ONLY". (7) Monies cleared by Telstra service personnel are returned to the phone's coin box and not accounted for independently of the normal payphone coin receipts. However, customers who have lost money can call Telstra's Customer Service Department on 132200 and have the money refunded, either as a credit on a nominated telephone account, or returned in coins. (8) General payphone receipts are used primarily to fund the installation, operation and maintenance of the payphone network. Family Court: Newcastle, New South Wales (Question No. 2867) Mr Allan Morris asked the Attorney General, upon notice, on 6 April 1998: (1) Following the retirement of Justice Renaud from the Family Court at Newcastle, will a new judge be appointed; if so when. (2) Will the financial and human resources available to the Family Court at Newcastle be held to at least their current levels. (3) Will the Government ensure the level of autonomy of the Family Court at Newcastle and its service of the region, including its outreach services, is maintained. Mr Williams-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Justice Renaud has given formal notice of her intention to resign as a judge from the Newcastle Registry of the Family Court in September 1998. Judges are appointed to the Court. Normally, the Government agrees to an appointment in a particular State, but it is a matter for the Chief Justice where the judge will be located in that State. Appointments are made after a process of broad consultation to ensure that the best possible candidates are identified. (2) The net Running Costs appropriation for the Family Court in the 1997/98 Budget was $106,535,000. In the 1998/99 Budget it is $107,229,000. The Court has indicated that the financial and human resources available to the Newcastle Registry will therefore be held to their current levels. (3) Parliament has made the Family Court a selfadministering agency where decisions about the management of its administrative, including financial affairs rest with the Court. Accordingly, the level of autonomy of the Newcastle Registry, its service to the region, including its outreach services, is a matter for the Court. Cairns Migrant Resource Centre: (Question No. 2870) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998: (1) Who was involved in the decision to cease core funding for the Cairns Migrant Resource Centre. (2) Did the Member for Leichhardt make representations to him, his office or his Department about the operation of the Caims Migrant Resource Centre; if so, what was the nature of the representaDepartment's tions. (3) What public processes, tendering or submission, were established before Cairns Centacare was selected to take over migrant services in Cairns. (4) What is the nature of his Department's agreement with Cairns Centacare and how does the agreement compare with the agreement which existed with the Cairns Migrant Resource Centre. (5) For what period has Cairns Centacare been contracted to provide migrant services in Cairns and how does it compare with the arrangement which existed with the Cairns Migrant Resource Centre. (6) What is the value of the contract between Cairns Centacare and his Department to provide migrant services in the region and how does it compare with the arrangement which existed with the Cairns Migrant Resource Centre. . (7) Is he able to state whether Cairns Centacare failed to renew a contract with the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs; if so, how does the value of the contract with that Department compare with the value of the contract with his Department. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Apart from me, staff in my Department's Brisbane, Cairns and Central Offices. (2) No formal representations were made to myself or my Department by the Member for Leichhardt. I am advised that the Member did express concerns about the operation of the Cairns at least MRC to my Department's North Queensland Regional Manager when he made a courtesy visit to the Member shortly after taking up his appointment in the region. (3) Cairns Centacare has not been selected to take over migrant services in Cairns. I announced on 25 March 1998 that the Community Settlement Services (CSS) Scheme workerbased grant, which I awarded to the Cairns MRC on 28 August 1997, would henceforth be managed under the auspices of Centacare Cairns. This grant Funding is covered by a Service Agreement. Centacare was judged to be an appropriate organisation to manage additional resources, at least in the interim, because it has a proven record of service delivery. The work program objectives of the Cairns MRC CSS Scheme worker-based grant were to enable the employment of a full-time worker for a period of twelve months to assist new arrivals and improve outreach to people from non-English speaking countries in rural and remote areas. These objectives closely approximate key settlement service objectives contained in the Cairns MRC work program that had been supported by my core funding. Continuation of the CMRC CSS Scheme grant by Centacare will therefore allow for the partial addressing of key settlement needs of migrants and refugees identified in the Cairns MRC core-funded work program, until alternative fuller service arrangements arising from a regional needs assessment are in place. (4) My Department's agreement with Cairns Centacare in relation to the CSS Scheme grant transferred from the Cairns MRC is referred to in (3) above. Cairns Centacare is also currently funded by my Department under a Service Agreement for a CSS Scheme worker which I awarded to the organisation on 28 August 1997 to assist newly arrived humanitarian entrants and migrants get access to services. My Department funded the Cairns MRC under two different programs. Under the Migrant Resource Centre Program, it received funding for two core staff, rent and a contribution towards operating costs. MRC funding was provided under a Service Agreement between the Commonwealth and the MRC. This funding will not be reallocated until I have considered the results of the current regional needs assessment. As referred to in (3), my Department had also provided funding to the Cairns MRC under the CSS Scheme. (5) The MRC Program funding to the Cairns MRC had been provided under a Service Agreement which, in the normal course of events, would have expired on 30 June 1998. When I announced on 25 March 1998 the termination of core funding to the Cairns MRC and the transfer MRC's CSS Scheme funding to Cairns Centacare, all CSS Scheme funding was to terminate on 30 September 1998. On 31 March 1998 I announced that organisations that had CSS Scheme worker-based grants would be offered a 12-month extension of those grants until 30 September 1999. This offer has been made to Cairns Centacare in relation to the CSS Scheme grant I awarded it last year. The future of the CSS Scheme grant transferred from Cairns MRC will be considered as part of the regional needs assessment. (6) For the 12 months to 30 September 1998, my Department is providing $48,358 to Cairns Centacare for a Level 2 CSS Scheme worker. The total amount of funding allocated to the Cairns MRC for the 12 months to 30 September 1998 was $162,396, which included $44,604 for a Level 1 CSS Scheme worker. As noted in (3), the grant for the Level 1 CSS Scheme worker is now managed under the auspices of Cairns Centacare. (7) I am unable to answer this question which should be put to my colleague, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Legal Services (Question No. 2888) Mr Bevis asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 Apri11998: Was Clayton Utz, NSW, selected to provide legal services under a tender gazetted as E8200356 Legal Fees-51 Far North Queensland Regiment: $10 000; if so, (a) what selection process was followed and (b) what is the nature of the legal services provided. Mr MCLachlan-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Clayton Utz Melbourne were selected to provide legal services under Purchase Order E8200356 Legal Fees-51 Far North Queensland Regiment. The Defence Estate Organisation has, following a competitive tender process, established a legal panel consisting of the following three firms: Clayton Utz, . Minter Ellison, and . Blake Dawson and Waldron. The value of the services provided by Clayton Utz in relation to this matter was $1 560. Purchase Order E8200356 was raised in the amount of $10 000 to allow for this specific advice and any other minor legal advice which may be required during the inception phase of the project. (a) Clayton Utz have been engaged in accordance with the Defence Estate Organisation's procedures for use of the legal panel. As the expected value for the provision of legal services in relation to the 51 FNQR Project was less than $15 000, one panel member was approached. (b) In regard to the nature of the legal services provided, Clayton Utz gave a legal assessment of a draft facilities acquisition strategy for the project. Because of the nature of the project, the draft delivery strategy proposed minor differences from standard delivery practices adopted within the Defence Estate Organisation, for the employment of the Project Consultant and Managing Contractor. Clayton Utz were asked to assess the legal implications of the proposed different approach, and whether it would require any amendments to the standard Defence contracts for these appointments. Wool Containers: Land Transport Costs (Question No. 2908)  Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998: (1) What is the range of total land transport costs involved in the transport of (a) 20 foot and (b) 40 foot containers of wool from farm gate to export container terminals in (i) New South Wales, (ii) Western Australia and (iii) Victoria. (2) What is the cost of each form of land transport referred to in part (1). Mr Vaile-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) and (2) The following information was provided by the Bureau of Transport Economics (BTE). "The BTE understands that containers are rarely, if ever, used to carry wool from the farm gate. Rather, wool is generally transported in bales by road from farms to a wool store. After sale, wool destined for export is transported to a facility where it is dumped (compressed), then loaded into a container and transported to a shipping terminal. Road transport would be used for short distance movements but rail is likely to carry any containers transhipped to an interstate port. As far as the BTE is aware, greasy wool is generally exported as dumped bales in 6 metre (20 foot) containers, although 12 metre (40 foot) boxes are sometimes used when shipping lines offer lower, back-loading rates for them out of Australia. The larger 12 metre boxes are also used sometimes for exports of scoured wool and wool tops A further complication in estimating costs is that some wool is transported to interstate ports for export. This can happen if wool growers consign their clip to an interstate city for auction (say from northern NSW to Brisbane), or if wool buyers consign their containers to an interstate port. Export statistics suggest that oniy a minor percentage of NA Average per farm Average for all farms selling wool (broker and private) Total quan- 1129 (0) tity of wool sold-kg Total quality 1935 (20) of wool sold privatelykg Quantity of 10184 (S) wool sold to brokers-kg Percentage 84 of wool sold to brokers% Population 15635 of farms selling wool-no. Average for all farms selling wool to a broker Quantity of 12849 (7) wool sold to brokers-kg the wool produced in NSW, Vic and WA is transhipped to another state for export but further research would be required to produce accurate estimates. ABARE [Australian Bureau of Agricultural Resource Economics] data (table attached) show average freight costs per kilogram paid in each state to transport wool from farm gate to store where the transport was arranged by the wool broker. The ABARE survey did not cover movements of wool where the transport was arranged by the farmer. As far as the BTE is aware, there are no generally published statistics available on post auction transport costs for wool, that is from the store to the port. According to ABARE, they are generally paid by buyers." It is therefore not possible to respond directly to the Honourable Member's question in the terms it was put. However, given advice from Wool Dumpers Australia Pty Ltd that the average 20 foot container transports 21,000kg of wool, the average freight bill for farms selling wool to a broker (which covers freight up to the time of auction) can notionally be equated to a cost per 20 foot container. The notional ABARE per container costs are approximately $395 for NSW, $181 for Victoria and $170 for WA.
